text:
Looks like a lot of technology is introduced to fix or alleviate a problem that was introduced and not there in older cars.


Bigger cars = Poor vision = sensor and cameras = poor driver habit of not actually looking
Run flats = cannot see loss in air till too late = tyre pressure sensor = poor driver habit of actually not checking even visually
Too much infotainment = driver distraction = lane keeping, autonomous braking etc.= poor driver habit of lack of self discipline and control
Too quiet, isolated and refined = low to no driver connectivity and stimulation = pipe fake engine notes and sounds = poor driver connection, disjointed perception of speed and driving reality.Ôªø

author: Michael Piperni

text:
To me analogue gagues, unless combined with a good digital screen as a part of it (e.g. new Mazda 3 or Kia Stinger), make the car feel dated. It is a matter of taste. Of course. 


Had a Renault Megane for a short while (2017 one) it had a digital instrument cluster. Looked really nice and made the car feel modern., even if the rest of the interior was nothing special. Now I drive a 2016 Polo (soon going to the new Corolla or Mazda 3) and it has very basic and simple cluster. I think it makes the cabin feel even more bland and dated than it already is. Some might like the simplicity of it, but I prefer to look ad an interior that feels new and fresh.  But then again I lease cars for 4 years or 150.000 km, so long-term reliability is not really a concern for me.


Some people say that analogue clusters feel timeless. I just can't look at it that way. 


I disagree with the whole distraction point. I have never felt that the screens in a car are distractions, far from it. If they work well you really don't have to look at them that much in the first place. And if you have navigation open sometimes you have to look, so in that situation it is easier to have it at leas a bit high up so you don't have to look down that much. Also bigger screens, within a limit, of course.... (Tesla).... Makes text and other things a lot easier to read and, if done right, makes on-screen buttons easier to tap. I still prefer a rotary dial over touch though.Ôªø

author: Funcle Ucker

text:
Dude, did you have to show an open toilet with yellowish water?  

I can't stand ultra low profile tyres on more and more cars. Expensive, harsh and noisy ride. 

Yeah, also hate fake vents. I love that Kia Stinger and am considering buying but as it's a twin turbo in the 6 cylinder, actual real vents would have been great to vent hot air.  If you go to the trouble of putting vents on the hood, just make them real.

I don't mind the tacked on infotainment systems but yes, make it intuitive.  Don't show the AC settings on that, show them in the AC controls. 

I can live with the electronic parking brake BUT put a light on the switch so you clearly know when you've applied it.  Mazda 3 has it, something like the Stinger tells you on the dash it's on. I prefer to have  basic information not on a dash.  Again with the Stinger, don't add unnecessary motorised functions. A Mazda has a manual sunshade on the sunroof. The Stinger has a motorised one. Again, I prefer to open the sunshade manually. 

I do however like electric steering adjustments as you can preset that along with seats, mirrors and HUD. And I do like electric boot releases as it's convenient for large ones like large fastbacks. I believe with the Stinger you can turn on or off the electric hatch but I may be wrong.Ôªø

author: ewanok

text:
HUGE problem coming up the pipe:
LED type dashboards.  Cars are expected to be in service ten years, at least, if not twenty or more.  LED and similar technologies simply do not have that sort of longevity.  When those over complicated digital displays fail, it essentially renders the car rolling scrap due to the expense of replacing them.

My sister has a CVT... I don't like it because it feels like a darn lawnmower.  All of my other cars have traditional transmissions so I'm used to those shift points but, knowing I'm driving a CVT I can handle not having those but... the engine is just... I dunno.  No real performance for having a single speed, and a horrible torque curve.Ôªø
author: Amzar Nacht

text:
All these gizmos added to modern cars will make people lease instead of buy. That way after the lease has expired in two or three years you hand the car back before any major problems start to develop. Someone else will buy it and they'll have to deal with the short lifespan electronic car.
Living in Australia my car is the all Australian Ford Falcon a car that's now been killed off. It has a center screen but it's not a touch screen. There is a menu button and you turn a knob and press the center part of the knob which is the OK button. I has bluetooth and ipod connectivity but there is no infotainment screen. So no android or iphone play. There is a local company which makes an infotainment replacement screen to enable android and iphone play but it costs $1,000 and that's fitting it yourself. My car has a few niceties but they're all worked with buttons you press or turn. 
My car is 10 years old now and no electronics or computerised bits have failed......yet. When I look at replacement vehicles I see lane departure warning fitted as standard or stop start fitted as standard or eye sight control and blind spot monitoring. My Falcon has none of those gizmos with no constant ding dings as you drive down the road. My car also has the near bullet proof "Barra" motor. I can see myself hanging onto my FG G6E for some time to come.Ôªø

author: Joe Devine

text:
I drive a GS450h, which has an isolated ride, stupidly complex drivetrain, a fully automatic electric parking brake, it's a hybrid so it does start/stop at 40mph and it has a dual-stage planetary transmission which acts like an insanely complex CVT. In terms of complex tech, the aircon will check which seats are actually occupied and only work in those areas by automatically controlling the air and seat temperatures, plus it moisturises your skin while it's at it.


Thing is though, it's also a ridiculous sleeper, especially considering I'm in the UK where the average car has about 150bhp (because fuel costs about 3x more here). I can see how those things would be annoying but when a manufacturer makes it work, they all make sense. I'm not suggesting the GS450h is the best car ever, but it's a good example of getting it right- it still handles incredibly well, goes like a rocket but then you shove it in eco mode and it's like driving a Rolls Royce (at least much closer than you'd expect for 1/5 of the cost). Plus, it's a Lexus so it's not going to break, even the mental transmission, which actually works well for both performance and cruising. The batteries even have a 10 year warranty, so no issues there.


I will say though, that they have to get it right for all this to be good. Since I used an example of Lexus getting it right, they also make the CT, which is I believe statistically the world's most reliable new car. It's also horrible. The suspension is too hard and the CVT in that feels like it's using what little power it has to just make an irritating noise, certainly not for performance. Stick a 6 speed torque convertor in it and it'd be fine. Not great, but fine.Ôªø
author: Apothecary Terry

text: I don't like the trends for recommended maintenance either.  Like lifetime fluids, or super high miles/kms between oil changes.  That is BS, there are plenty of tests showing a wide variety of fluids that we use do not last as long as what the OEM says they do.  Oh, the OEM does not have the money/resources (because finance departments wouldn't allow it) to develop their own fluids either so please don't get sucked in believing that (doesn't make sense to do that anyways), they just re-package stuff and crank the price.  Financial decisions do not make a car better, for example:  the new Supra (yes I'm going there) was a car created by financial decisions rather than Engineering their own.  They literally squashed the FT1 body front to back and side to side to get it to fit over a Z4.  The hood had to be re-designed to suit as well.  It is ok though as Marketing comes to the rescue to boost a cars appeal and most of the time they are trying too hard and it is embarrassing and makes me cringe.Ôªø

text: I don't have any of these problems. I drive a 1990 Toyota MR2. It has two litre normally aspirated engine driving through a 5 speed manual gear box. It has no power steering and only a little boost on the brakes. I get a LOT of information about the road by the vibrations and feel that comes through the steering wheel. This does help on those occasions when I hit a corner a little hard and come out of it sideways. While the car does have electric mirrors, it has no central locking and to make the windows go up and down I have to use a small lever that manually rotates winders that move the windows. I have a radio/tape deck as my only extra electronics and I love my little car.  It is a drivers car. It will do EXACTLY what I tell it do do, without any complaints or any electronics trying to "save" me.Ôªø

author: Howie Isaacks

text: Wait people's complaints with the start/stop makes more sense in a traffic jam then in rural area. In a traffic jam you can be breaking only to stop for a second or two before starting again to stop in a few seconds again. People might have a point that it is hard on the engine but if you are doing this at a traffic light in town then it's either a very compact city or you need to go back to driving school because you cant keep your foot on the break petal. The car isnt designed to release the start-stop until you remove you foot from breaking. It's because people are too antsy and impatient that the releasing occurs. Just keep your foot down if you are breaking until the situation changes. A good driver should be aware of their habits, good and bad.Ôªø

author: U F

text: Fun fact, when you open one window in a car that is less than ten years old, the air coming in will be split by the pillar behind the window, and it will cause an extremely uncomfortable vibration that irritates every person in the vehicle. This behavior is comparable to an organ pipe. When you think organ, think church, or theater. They have pipes ranging in size from the size of a pencil to the length of a wooden power line pole. The range in size is to cover every note and pitch on an equally tempered keyboard instrument, which the pipe organ is. The pitch is measured in feet. Middle c is in the 8 foot pitch range. Higher pitches go up, 4', 2' 1', and even some fractions in between like 5 and 2/3'. Lower pitches go down, 16', 32' 64'. There is a variety of types of pipes that might extend the full length, as in open pipes, some that are half the labeled pitch length,  as in stopped pipes, and also twice the length, as in overblown pipes. Then there are pipes designed to fit in a small space, while still filling their required length to resonate at the proper pitch. These are Mitered, or 'bent' around like a concert tuba, or forwards like a saxophone. This is purely compensating for limited space. Pipes can have different voices. This is based on their speaking element, which can be flue, like a recorder, and reed, like an oboe. It is also based on their voicing, which is very mathematical in some ways, and I don't understand it yet. Now that you know more about a pipe organ, I will get to the point. The vibrating air inside the car resonates within the passenger cabin when split by the window frame. When the valve under a flue pipe is opened and the air flows into it, it encounters a barrier which has a slit facing the front of the pipe. The slit allows air through, and guides it towards a splitter. The air runs into the splitter, and is guided either outside of the pipe or into the resonator. The air that goes into the resonator vibrates with increasing intensity, and it becomes audible, or inaudible, sound. Now you can see the comparison; the flue is the window, and the passenger cabin is the resonator. It is a fun comparison for me when I find myself in one of these newer motor vehicles, and I have the natural instinct to open the window. I realize my mistake, and as the cabin begins to resonate, I close the window, because everybody hates that. On with the air conditioner, I suppose.Ôªø
author: MrManiac3

text: The problem you describe when only one window is down causing resonance is actually because of one thing that is better on newer cars. go look at the door seals. THERE ARE TWO Of THEM. The double door seal keeps out road noise and when one window is down the cabin becomes pressurized. In older cars the air would just leak out of the doors and there is no resonance.Ôªø
author: Larry Schwartz

text: Larry Schwartz that is exactly right. It seems, from what I have seen just in life, that the double seal came about in the mid to late 90s, as I've seen it in vehicles that I've ridden in. I also recall that a couple vehicles from the late 80s that I have looked closely at do not have a double seal. The cars from the 90s/early 2000s that I have had experience with noticeably did not resonate in such an uncomfortable way. This can probably be attributed to the age of the vehicle, the breakdown of that seal over time, and the high probability that the seals were not manufactured properly. Both options--proper seal or improper seal--have their trade offs. A proper seal insulates a bit of noise coming into the cabin, but when windows are open, the wind causes uncomfortable vibration. An improper seal allows the air to flow more smoothly in the cabin by comparison, and only blows your hair around and causes noise. When the windows are closed, less noise from outside the cabin is blocked from entering, and as you say, you can hear more of the road. There are other factors to hearing the road, such as suspension stiffness and tire diameter, as well as road quality to begin with. But ignoring that, window seal does have a large influence on noise. When it comes down to it, it's the driver's preference. Does the driver want a quiet car? Does the driver want windows that can be opened on the highway? Does the driver want to understand the car, or does the driver want the car to shush? It's up to the driver to decide.Ôªø
author: MrManiac3

text: I love my old car. It's not wickedly overstyled with hundreds of sharp pointless angles, there's no big stupid gross grill, the doors aren't ' dented ' in like so many newer models, I have a REAL spare tire and a REAL key, there's no distracting tv screen with menus within menus making it hard to find certain functions, all the controls have REAL knobs and buttons that are so easy to use, after 17 years I've got them all memorized and can adjust things without even taking my eyes off the road, and if I have to check the gauges, they're right in front of me, not the centre console, and they're simple and quick to check. My car doesn't shut off at a stop sign, I'd really, really hate that, there's no stupid sensors everywhere that can and WILL fail in time, ALL the fluids are easy to check and replace, there's no driver assisted anything, which has forced me to become a better driver over the years, it's far cheaper to fix anything on my car, and after all these years, my V6 still runs like a clock, unlike so many turbocharged 4 bangers that are crapping out faster than you can say ' gigantic repair bill ' and my 4 speed automatic transmission is still functioning flawlessly, and it even came with a block heater as standard equipment because not everyone lives in Florida. What I'm doing at this point is waiting until they start to delete the most obnoxious trends in styling and function regarding ICE cars, either that or until they come up with an electric car that will give me 500 real world miles worth of range with a 25k price tag, whichever comes first. Screw new cars because a lot of their ' features ' are designed to screw YOU, unless of course you actually think that a thousand dollars for a headlight is reasonable. I don't.Ôªø

text:
The $ you think you're saving in gas from the idle-off feature will quickly evaporate when the starter motor and ring gear have to be replaced.   That can run into the multiple thousands.

text: People that whine about start-stop from a wear perspective are just dumb consumers that don't know anything about the system. They use starters that are designed for way more starts than you will ever do in the 15+ years you own that thing and starting a motor once it heats up has almost no effect on wear because the oil is already warm and lubing everything up. If people don't like the feeling of it, that's a different issue. Also, if the feel is the issue, like any new feel in a car, you get used to it and then enjoy the extra couple bucks you save in gas each week. People like to say it does nothing, but that is because they have no concept of how much they spend in fuel.Ôªø

text: Oh I know I'm late to this but where do I start?   FWD "Sport sedans" Gimme a break. Giant center consoles that block my ability to 'manspread.' Center consoles with buttons far enough away that I have to change my position to reach. Hate to break it to the passengers in the vehicle, the driver is the most important person in the cab and everything should be comfortably within reach of the driver. Steering wheels with buttons all over it. That chaps my ass to no end. I just want a steering wheel with 1 button on it.... HORN. The rest can and is on the dash/console anyway. Non-dimable dashboards and LCDs on the console. It's bad enough I'm blinded by assholes with HIDs and white lights, I don't need it from within the car. It's dark, I don't need the dash to be light up ultra bright to compete with the moon. Super bright headlights. For the last few years, I've had to start using night driving glasses because of the amount of people using high K, ultra bright headlights that are barely any different than the car's highbeams. Engineering traps as part of the design to screw up the car and your wallet when you need something fixed.Ôªø

author: transikk

text: Nobody will probably read this but there are a few topics discussed in this video that are explained pretty well by the Engineering Explained channel. A few things he has talked about that stood out to me in this video are- Auto start stop. Ive Been informed that the auto start stop vehicles actually have a second starter motor specifically for that use. If you pay attention, listen to the difference in time it takes to start a vehicle normally and when the vehicle auto starts. The Auto start is much quicker. Along with that, in an engineering explained video fuel consumption is talked about. An engine idling for about anything over 30sec uses more fuel than starting the engine. With that said, I think if companies use the auto start stop they should shut the engine off after it becomes wasted fuel instead of immediately when you stop. Lastly every car I've driven that has a start stop has had a switch or button that is easily accessible to turn the feature off. You dont have to dig through settings and menus to turn it off. One press of a button and you're good to go.Ôªø
author: Drew N Cars

text: Not that I read this thread, but you must not have driven a GM car as most models don't have a start/stop button to disable. I'd go looking for the fuse or tune it if that were the case for me, but luckily my car doesn't have it.  IMHO, these systems should have feature/ability to disable permanently.  I had one for 2 years in a (company car)'17 Ford Fusion and didn't care for some of the timing of when it turned off typically right when I needed it to go for immediate take off - say to make a quick left out of a neighborhood onto a busy road.  Pain if I didn't remember to disable when I started the car.  Your idea of turning off after it starts wasting fuel, wouldn't really work due to timing - how would it know if the stop light I was at changed at the 35 second mark or 2 minute mark?  Shutting down after 30 secs for example would mean it's idling for 30 seconds, then off for 5 wasting that initial 30 sec. fuel burn off.  For the extra engineering and more expensive components needed to support it, I would put start/stop feature high on my don't like list of modern cars trends.Ôªø

author: Max Nix

text:
My number one complaint about cars is that they are designed to be assembled at a factory not to be serviced.  The optimization of manufacturing is now so invasive, as to make it impossible to repair simple things without dissembling huge chucks of a car. The lack of a dip stick is a perfect example.  Another one is having to remove the entire front of a car to replace a water pump. Or even worse the ludicrous number of plastic trim clips I break off when adding after market stereo parts or other electronics. 

Cars are being manufactured like Iphones, only you don't keep your Iphone for 5-10 years. Then sell it to someone else  who has it for another 5-10 years.  With the latest generations of cars, I will go broke maintaining them. Not because the parts are expensive but because the number of hours it takes to do a job has gone through the roof. 

My 86 VW golf took me less than an hour and a couple of wrenches to change the fan belts. My 07 takes my mechanic 2 hours to change the serpentine belt. A job that was doable in my front yard for less than 30$ is now a 300$ mechanics job.  I have watched a group of mechanics remove an air cooled beetle engine rebuild it and reinstall it in 1 day.  You cant install a create motor in an empty engine bay in one day anymore.Ôªø

text: The SUV or The Chelsea Tractor as we call them in the UK are literally the worst invention or trend ever. The madness behind it is sexist in that it assumes women to be poorer drivers than men so they need a big load of metal around them to protect them on the school run. The knock on effect of this is it does actually end up making women drivers take risks they wouldn't normally take as they have the protection of 3 tons of steel around them. This is fine and dandy for them but not too cool when you are in a normal person's car watching a woman too afraid to drive through a small puddle at the road's edge and instead decides to nearly kill you as she swerves in to your lane to avoid dirtying the alloy rims....or exposes all her precious cargo of children to the extreme risk of collision by pulling out of a junction in front of you when all she had to do to be safe is wait the 10 seconds it would take for you to pass on by safely and then she is safe to pull out as as there is nothing behind you...which she would know if she could be bothered to look instead of texting and just blindly following whatever the car in front has done. And before you all get on my case about slating women drivers...the men are no better...to make an instant dick head...just add 1 x man to a Range Rover or other similarly useless when off-road vehicle. Indicators (turn signals) not needed...driving standards out the fucking window. These piles of shit bring out the worst in people. I used to have to drive a Range Rover periodically for work and I actually started to dislike myself.Ôªø

text:
I am 6'4" tall, and center panels that encroach on the driving wheel are one of my big bitches. Since my legs do not fit under the steering wheel, my knee needs that lateral space. Also, rear-view mirrors often block my forward-rightward vision, as they are too low for me. 
I prefer physical knobs, as they can be operated by touch alone, while screens take my eyes off the road uncomfortably long.
I switched to an EV four years ago, and greatly appreciate getting out of the CO2 emission rat race (here is Sweden no fossil fuel is used in generating electricity).Ôªø

author: Alexander Floryszak

text:
Listen to me automakers.  You are going to go broke very soon as your business model is about to crash.  I will no longer buy a new car.  I'm looking for a very simple car that is reliable and can get 300K miles.  Looks like I will buying an old 1990s Toyota or Honda.  I can get a rebuilt engine and transmission for say $5000.  Put in a new clutch and suspension components for $1500.  Bring the seats to an upholster for $1000.  Repaint and fix rust for $2000.  Throw in $2000 for miscellaneous stuff.  Figure on $2000 for the used car.  The total is $13,500 for a car that will do 300K miles.  Insurance will be really cheap too, as well as registration.  Guess what automakers, I have saved a ton of money that I can spend on something that I feel is important.  BTW the fuel mileage on the old small cars is just as good as new cars.  If I need more space I will put on a $300 roof rack.  The only thing missing is airbags.  However, if people quit using their cell phone in the car and messing with the undecipherable infotainment system, they wouldn't be getting in crashes and needing air bags.

I will have a real dipstick, full spare tire and not runflats, windows I can actually look out, a radio I can figure out, and simple heating knobs and levers.  Parts are also really cheap.

Enough is enough!!!  Detroit you are getting rid of small reliable cars so you can cash in on truck and SUV market.  BTW...most new trucks and SUVs will NOT get 100K miles with our spending $10,000 for something that breaks.  I will not play.

Consumers...pull your head out of your ass.  Don't play their game.  Go to the dealership or automaker web page and say you will no longer buy into this crap.  Alas...I know you won't do it because most people are just downright stupid (not just ignorant).

I have used/programmed computers since 1974 and understand technology.  Car technology has gone amuck.Ôªø

text: Auto stop/start doesn't save enough fuel to justify its inclusion. My car tells me how much fuel it supposedly saves and even in horrible city traffic it only ammounts to a few litres per annum. Compare that to the increased battery price and it's actually more expensive. In Australia a typical car battery costs $169 while a stop/start battery costs anywhere from $350 to $600+. That's equivalent to paying for about 60 litres of extra fuel per annum. That means that any fuel savings are negated by the cost of a new battery.Ôªø

I will never buy a car over 2009 because I refuse to drive anything with electric gas pedal, brakes or steering. I don't want to "send a signal" to advance, or stop or turn. I just want to control all of that in direct action and so I will never buy those cars. Never. text: Thanks for the follow-up video. I don't care about many of these criticisms though, my car is just a tool for getting me, passengers and cargo from one place to another, in the most environmentally friendly, less costly and most ethical way. I don't need to "enjoy" the "driving experience" or "feel the road," as long as it is easy to drive. I am not driving to drive, I think it's a luxury and environmental and ethical aberration: Even if you drive an EV, you are unnecessarily driving up the production of electricity, some from natural gas or coal, you are using up the petroleum tar on the roads, driving insurance costs up, driving fatal accidents and microparticulates up, etc. And there are of course many alternatives to owning or driving a car every time, especially if you live in a city.Ôªø
author: 33Chimel33

text:
The huge array of driver assists is becoming detrimental to driving ability in my opinion.  They certainly made driving safer but they're removing the need for drivers to have any skill at all.  Stamp on the brakes with your lead foot?  No worries, ABS will sort that for you.  Do the same to the accelerator? No problem, traction control will take over.  Driving too fast in slippery corners?  Stability control has your back.  Hell, you don't even need to be able to park or remain a safe distance from the car in front these days.

And what's the benefit of all this technology?  Fewer crashes, yes.  But manufacturers now put horrendously distracting touch screens in the dashboard to make sure all this tech comes into play.

Drivers now feel utterly safe while driving their cars in a very unsafe manner.Ôªø

author: Tim Congrove

text:
I really hate modern cars, in general.  I can't stand that manual transmissions are nt even available in many models.  I passionately hate the lack of choice in vehicle design.  If i want a compact, midsize, full-size sedan , coupe, wagon, van, commercial van, SUV, Crossover,  or whatever, it is FWD.  I am sick of FWD.  It is inherently inferiour!  It cost 2x as much to rebuild!  There are some good FWD cars, but all of them would be 10 times better if they were RWD!  

I hate how needlessly complex cars are.  It is obscene.  The law should require cars to be first and foremost as simple as possible and user-serviceable.  I want to see more classic style.  Modern style is vulgar.  Smaller rims would be nice.  Tyres cost too much and rims are too big.  

I really think the easiest fix for all this would be to turn the clock back a few decades.  

I. Will. Not. Consider. Buying. A. New. Car.  

To me, the 2004 Explorer is newer than I'm comfortable with, but it's a much more traditional and rugged vehicle than the current generation of rolling rubbish, and will probably outlast most of it!Ôªø

author: Troy Allen

text:
CUVs and SUVs are selling more because sedans keep getting lower and lower to the ground. 
Look at how much lower the new Accord and Civics are to the ground compared to the previous generation models.
Pretty soon, sedans are going to have seats as low as a Camaro. Civic is almost there.
The roof lines on sedans are sloping and getting lower too so there isn't enough head room for adults in the back seat.
This is forcing more and more people into CUVs so they can have a more upright seating position and back seat room.  
In a few years, you will be required to buy a CUV or SUV if you don't want to be sitting on the floor with your legs straight out in front or your knees in your face in the back seat.
Then people see more and more of their neighbors with CUVs and they buy them to fit in with the trend and manufacturers shift production to CUVs and cancel sedans like Ford is.Ôªø

text:
This is a very interesting discussion, presented very well. I agree with some of the things people are complaining about, many are very real. At the same time, being a retired senior, I also see and hear a lot of people complaining about these ‚Äúdang newfangled contraptions!‚Äú back in the 60s people were complaining about how they didn‚Äôt build cars like they did in the 40s. There‚Äôs always somebody, mostly us older people, complaining that the new whatever isn‚Äôt as good as the old whatever. Truth is, time marches on. Things change, such as concerns about the environment, and we have to change with them. I much prefer the cars of today as they are much much safer (while passenger miles are way way up, deaths are way way down) and pollute much less, while using less fuel. Of course, I have grandchildren, which makes me care about such things. 
As to modern styling trends, since I survived the fins of the late 50s, I can survive anything!üòÜÔªø
author: Itsalgud1

text: I would like to see all safety mandates subjected to a cost-benefit analysis. For every life a seatbelt saves, the cost is around $60 thousand, considering all the money paid for every car to have them. For every life an airbag saves, the cost is about $2 million. (From an analysis done by Freakanomics economist Steve Levitt.) How many other lives could be saved if that 2 million were allocated toward more cost-effective lifesaving measures? A lot of what makes newer cars safer is crush zones, roll cages, and collapsible steering columns, and these don't have to be expensive. Screw the air bags.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text:
grizzlygrizzle 
I‚Äôm not confident in your source. In any case, you sound like a Bridgestone tire engineer, justifying to his management why they shouldn‚Äôt fix their tires so they can maximize their profits on the backs of dead people and their families!üòñÔªø
author: Itsalgud1

text: @Itsalgud1 -- I have no conflict of interest here, no financial stake in whether or not cars are festooned with marginally-effective mandated safety items. I do have preferences for elegant simplicity in engineering, for cost-benefit analyses for economic policies, and for anti-fascist political policies that don't mandate dependency on centralized power, whether they're governmental or corporate.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text:
grizzlygrizzle 
Maybe I wasn‚Äôt clear, or maybe you just wanted to miss the point! I did not say that you had any vested interest in any of this, only that you were putting a price on human lives. Also, as most of you statistically minded types conveniently forget, it‚Äôs very hard to measure the cost of 20,000 deaths a year to factor into your cost benefit analysis. As to ‚Äúmarginally successful ‚Äúsafety regulations, I gather that you haven‚Äôt bothered to check highway safety statistics over the last 20 or 30 years.Ôªø
author: Itsalgud1

text:
@Itsalgud1 -- Guilty as charged, and proud of it. In the real world, money doesn't grow on trees. And other resources are finite. I'm not a fan of the "If it saves one life..." and "It's for the children" arguments, because they often amount to virtue signalling and lead to emotion-driven misallocations that do more harm than good. Utopian states that focus on safety and security at the expense of liberty and reason historically go broke or end up in genocide. 
-- Actually I'm quite familiar with highway safety statistics over the past few decades. I'm also familiar with the stats for hospital deaths due to errors, which outweigh all highway deaths by a factor of about 12. Saving lives requires choices and allocations. 
-- Light trucks (SUVs, pickups, and vans) had, in 2012, a 47% higher fatality rate than cars in single-vehicle crashes, presumably due to their higher centers of gravity. Single-vehicle crashes accounted for 55% of all highway deaths. Shouldn't we do something to discourage non-essential SUV purchases, like extending the left-lane ban on highways to light trucks? That could discourage a lot of people from buying SUVs, cost virtually nothing, and even generate revenue.
-- As cars become more complicated, they become more expensive to fix, and more disposable. How much environmental damage results from having to make new cars when old ones might have been kept running? And how much fuel efficiency is lost, now that an economy car today weighs about twice what an economy car weighed 40 years ago? It's all about choices and consequences. Sentimental utopianism is no way to run a country.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text:
grizzlygrizzle 
Great phraseology! ‚ÄúSentimental utopianism‚Äú as a metaphor for ‚Äú people who care about other people and would like to live in a better world‚Äù. Obviously, a Trump supporter.Ôªø
author: Itsalgud1

text: @Itsalgud1 Sentimental utopianism was what motivated the French Revolution, the Russian Revolution, and numerous other leftist takeovers. What's the bodycount for sentimental utopianism in the 20th century? More than 100 million? Our moral impulses may begin with our sentiments, but in advanced, complicated nations, they can't end there.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text: I don't suppose less driving is a goal? If driving is left to only the people who enjoy it, there would be fewer vehicles on the road. For the people who don't care about their motor vehicles, it would make sense to provide public transit, but not everyone cozies up to that idea. That is probably due to their preconceived notions and past experiences with public transit. More attention towards public transit could bring such features as private cabins and cleaner passenger environments. Such things would improve passenger experiences. Of course, a market can't be driven in a direction that has little interest, and thinking about such a goal simplistically, ignoring factors that influence change and factors that cause disapproval among consumers won't allow you to influence effectively. Considering the variety of communities in the United States, those which have dense infrastructures and those that don't, you can see where this market would be focused, and where it wouldn't. That is ignoring public interest in public transit, which is especially low in suburban communities. There is another way to discourage driving on top of that. That is making the world come to the consumer. This can range from walking downtown for your groceries and everything ooh may need, to delivery of any necessity and at home work. I'm not interested in going down that rabbit hole. Nor am I interested in public transit, beyond historical examples, going back before the middle twentieth century. My interests lie in the antique; clothing, architecture, theaters, music, films, television, etcetera. I'm not a fan of public interests that defined the common interest, such as consumerism, drugs and alcohol, trends, and ignorance. I still find it interesting in historical context, though. There are things that I find exceptional. My favorite topics are theater organ, aeroplane, and automobile. I'm glad that I was born more recent, as organizations that promote such antique pieces of history are more accessible than ever, and there are more people who are open to supporting them for whatever reason. Being born in the twenty first century, if just by several months, I don't have decades of experience and wisdom. You may assume arrogance and self assuredness, but I feel no need to defend my beliefs or propositions. You may also perceive that there is no rhyme or reason in my ramblings. Then, as it may be, this passage is a meaningless mess of words.Ôªø

author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: @Matthew Jenkinson -- If people would wear their seatbelts, that would eliminate a large part of the need for airbags. Seatbelts, aside from being cheaper by far, have the added advantage of being a safety measure that requires participation, instead of relying on some abstract outside agent to protect oneself. I worked for decades in construction, and learned to take responsibility for my own safety, and that contributed to my sense of personal responsibility. And I use my seatbelt every time I drive.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text: @D'Arcy Jousset -- Reading comprehension requires attention. I cited my source.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text: @Itsalgud1 -- I have experienced the loss of several loved ones, and I'm well aware of how it feels. But I also recognize that policy makers have to make policy for strangers if those policies are going to have any hope of working in a world of limited resources that have to be allocated. If you extrapolate your emotional criterion for policy making, we would spend so much on transport safety that we would have to cut back on food or education or medicine. And we'd also be a lot more likely to go to war over relatively minor international incidents. Emotions are unreliable indicators of reality, and unreliable criteria for decisions.Ôªø
author: grizzlygrizzle

text:
@grizzlygrizzle Sure, but we are talking about the purchasing decisions of private citizens that prefer cars with multiple airbags because they are objectively safer, as shown by crash tests, regardless of the fact that the dollars per life saved are supposedly high (I don't like the methodology used for the $2m number). Unless you're saying the state should mandate that people hand over their money to more worthwhile programs instead of spending it on their own safety?

Like it or not, airbags are not that expensive, replacement cost is not equivalent to construction cost. I would agree with a mandate that makes car designs consider reasonable replaceability of parts like that, although if all the airbags in a car have gone off I'd be more concerned with whether that car is still driveable or not - sure, there will be cases where it was, but I would guess in the vast minority.Ôªø
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text:
@Matthew Jenkinson -- First, did you read through Levitt's study carefully enough to examine the methodology? He wasn't looking at replacement cost, but original installation cost.
-- Second, if consumers choose airbags so overwhelmingly, then there's no need to make them mandatory. The secondary issue here is one of government interference with the minutiae of citizens' lives and purchasing decisions. And those who pressed for the original mandate were definitely pushing for increasing government control of citizens' lives as a general policy (Claybrook, Nader, et al.). This in turn shrinks the domain of personal responsibility, and the more a society shrinks that domain, the more it creates a class of dependents who require even more government support and guidance, which in turn, allows government bureaucrats to gain even more power. It's just one of thousands of little steps in the direction of elitist totalitarianism. Some government involvement in safety regulations are necessary, but they should be chosen carefully. Personal responsibility and self-reliance aren't just personal choices. They're strength training, and people who are conditioned to avoid them become increasingly parasitic and weaken the country.Ôªø

text: the problem is hyper-complexity. this notion applies to most aspects of 'modern' society. with respect to vehicles, from the 1950s to the 1990s the increase in complexity was very favorable. implementation of technologies, refinement of materials and building processes were all beneficial to the driver. however, we have progressed well beyond the point of diminishing returns. useless car models (suvs), shorter service life/disposable cars (planned/perceived obsolescence), useless technologies (stop/start, auto parking, brake assist, etc.) are all symptoms of a greater problem. unfortunately, as cars become more 'user friendly,' allowing more of the population to operate a vehicle, the base competence level required to operate a vehicle also drops. If a person can't park without a reversing camera, said person should not be on the road. it is that simple.Ôªø

Not too much tech but enough to even be called nice. Especially blind spot monitoring. I will say that does help when you try to merge and didn't see a car even before looking over. 

 I do like my manual parking brake. I just know it won't break because it actually is mechanical. Electronic parking brakes feel like they do nothing and it's pointless. Totally a waste and putrid. The 2018 3 has it.

Now I feel like cars are made for a purpose. Well, individually each car. Some to compete for sportiness, some for the softest ride, some for the most premium interior, but honestly, it all seems to be the same and there's not a clear definition anymore of what is luxury like back in the 90s and everyone thought BMW and Porche and Audi were luxury. All the economy cars are catching up. I feel like that's the problem is really now all cars seem to be getting that luxury feel to them because of all the distractions and self driving aid. 

BTW if I don't have fake carbon fiber where I put my fingers to roll down my window, I most definitely won't want gloss piano black or a really nice material where I can see finger prints and scratches constantly. text:
When I see many modern cars I can only see crowds saying: "We need more cowbells!"
Plastic cars full with sketchy bells and whistles, though some vehicles might have better quality in them.
I'm also very skeptical of making purely electronic commands where your safety might be compromised if you have any electrical/electronic issue, just like the discussion around Airbus'fly-by-wire vs. Boeing's old hydraulic and wire redundancy systems and those are aviation quality, while mass production customer goods can't really maintain that level of quality! Wired tech can be very practical, specially if we're worried about making cars lighter and want to use more space for comfort, but the reliability of certain systems can't be messed with! Besides, eventhough vibration is very bad not only for your car but for people's health, which shows in long trips, completely disconnecting the feeling of the road from the driver might make it more dangerous in certain conditions, like when tires start to slip and such, making you more dependent on your vision and the inner ear labyrinth, both being "numbed" with all the bells and whistles, smartphones, media systems, etc.Ôªø

text:
You totally missed the point on 9 and 10 speed transmissions. On modern engines that hit the torque band at low rpms, the higher gears allow the vehicle to sit in the torque band for a larger amount of time. 

Also you missed the ball on keyless entry too. All vehicles with keyless entry have a physical key built in. Auto manufacturers aren't stupid. Of course you can get into you car with a dead battery. Also beside the shifter there is usually a plastic bit that can be popped off to shift the transmission into neutral to jump the car.Ôªø

author: Austin A

text:
The worst trend to me is faster and faster product cycles and new tech every other year. In the 90's my dad bought a car and basically drove it, till the mileage went too high, then he bought a new car that had basically the same features, maybe a CD player instead of a tape deck, but that's it. 
Now there is so much financial pressure on people to buy a new car every 2 years, if you want to stay relevant. 
My 2014 Accord, in mint condition got called old and 'featureless' just yesterday....10 years ago, a 4 year old car with 45,000 miles was like perfectly fine.
Honestly, car manufatcturers are financially raping us and we dance to their fiddle, just to stay socially relevant and not beeing 'that dude' driving aroound in a car with analog gauge clusters and no LED lights and a CD changer in the trunk etc. - Worrysome!Ôªø

text: My biggest complaint with modern cars is the lack of factory forged pistons and or con rods. So much cost cutting and unnecessary weight reduction has gone into ‚Äúenthusiast‚Äù engines that now every turbocharged car is basically a ticking time bomb. We have subaru‚Äôs fa20 dit with non axial off set flimsy ass conrods (funny tho because I just picked up a 2019 series grey) that bend under high load conditions even in its stock configuration, the focus rs‚Äôs famous head gasket scandal which I personally believe was intended as a way to save money because the 2.3 eco boost in the rs and mustang were very close to identical, the subaru wrx sti‚Äôs still on going ringland failure which has now been addressed in court but hey at least you got forged con rods for 2019 because fuck you if you bought a type RA. Long gone are the days of the 4g63,Ej207,F20, 4b11‚Äôs, pre ringland failure ej257‚Äôs, disi mzr. All im saying is I rather replace transmission‚Äôs all day long than to pull a motor and rebuild it and I can only imagine the pain people will feel who aren‚Äôt mechanically inclined.Ôªø

text: I want vehicles from the 60's.  I don't know what I like better, there are NO computers or they actually WORK correctly.  I haven't owned a vehicle in the last 20-30 years that actually worked like it was supposed to.  For instance, I owned a 1996 Chevy Silverado with a manual transmission.  The engine was programed to hold the idle to 1500 RPM until you almost came to a stop because the automatic transmission vehicles need that to keep from going dead when the A/C was on. It was MASSIVELY annoying in a manual vehicle.  Everything possible is regulated and controlled from some computer lab.  I guess, it boils down to the same thing.  Take away the computers and they work right.Ôªø

text: Cars have to be made less reliable nowadays because the baby boom is over and the economy did so well that the market got fully saturated. text: Wait, so in modern cars, you can't feel ANY feedback through the steering column? Damn, that has to be REALLY dangerous in the winter. I can't count the number of times that I saved myself because I felt the car starting to lose traction on snowy roads through the steering column and corrected my steering to prevent sliding in the first place. WTF are drivers supposed to do if you can't feel this kind of stuff through your steering and suspension systems? This is stuff you NEED to feel to drive safely. And also, you said "I understand why cars need them" (the LCD screens). No, cars don't NEED LCD screens. We went through 100+ years of cars that had no LCD screens at all and they worked fine. My 2010 Impala doesn't have any LCD screens, and I never felt like it needed any whatsoever. As long as you can give me basic information through LEDs on the dash like it does (mileage, compass, temp, tire PSI, etc), then that's all I need. Also, on styling, I'd like to point out how every car looks the same, 'cept for minor differences in the front. Anybody remember the day you could tell a Pontiac from a Ford from a Chevy because the entire body looked different? Remember when you saw a car pull in and you immediately said "Hey, look at that nice Corvette?" Nowadays, if I can't see a logo on the car somehwere, I couldn't tell you what brand/make/model it is because they all look the fricken same anymore. No individual personality, they're all the same except for the ultra-high end cars. I shouldn't need to dump $100k+ into a car just to get something that looks different than the common car.Ôªø

text: Automotive journalists need to go back to reporting on cars, and stop trying to create trends. You mentioned in your video how many of these annoying new car features were born out of the automotive journalists' insistence for them. It's as though all the magazines collaborate to latch onto the same new feature idea and insist that any vehicle not having it isn't up to par, forcing the manufacturers to begin including it in order to receive favorable reviews. They did this in the 80s and 90s with cup holders, and then again with iDrive-type console joystick controllers and touch screens in the 2000s. Now they're doing it with high-definition backup cameras. And then when these new features are inevitably seen as obnoxious or unnecessary, the journalists do a 180 and begin decrying them. Automotive writers need to get out of the product planning business.Ôªø

text: Sorry, i have to comment on some things that really bug me. Headlights where to change a bulb requires that you dismantle the front of the car. The number of people who don't seem to have the faintest idea how to position a car for parking etc. Here in the UK 2mm of snow and the country stops and the way to approach a slippery up hill gradient is as follows:- first approach the hill while holding everyone else back. When you reach the bottom you floor the throttle and turn the hill into an ice rink with the steering on a full lock then give up and pronounce the hill impassable and abandon your car sideways so nobody else can get by. This happened to me once. I hung back and waited for the idiot to give up then i simply indicated and drove around them and carried on up the hill. The look on the other drivers face was priceless. It seems now that you have to drive while staring at the speedo and looking out for cameras in order to avoid fines and i am talking about slipping a couple of mph over the limit which can be achieved unintentionally on overrun going down hill. One last thing. early model voice command telephone dialling on Range Rovers. I speak good clear english but could i get it to understand the word "eight". I tried all sorts of different accents and it gave me all sorts of different numbers so i gave up.Ôªø

text: The worst thing is when people get this whole elitist mentality about how "green" they are when they buy a new "eco" car, completely ignoring the impact that manufacturing has on the environment when they get a new car every few years.Ôªø
author: John Klise

text: There is some merit to this, but with a recent interest in EVs I've become aware of how much of the environmental impact is from manufacturing and how much from running. Spoiler alert: manufacturing is a small fraction, unless you drive an EV charged by renewables.Ôªø
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: @Matthew Jenkinson Funny you mention EV's because the batteries they rely upon are a very dirty business.Ôªø
author: John Klise

text: @John Klise not as dirty as 20 years of burning fossil fuels, but sure, go stick your fingers in your ears and sing.Ôªø
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: @Matthew Jenkinson It is ironic for you to say "go stick your fingers in your ears and sing" when that is exactly what you are doing right now. Regardless of how bad fossil fuel is, the fact remains that electric cars are far from being without their own drawbacks and there is also the fact that the energy they depend upon largely comes from fossil fuels such as coal. In other words the technology isn't nearly as clean as it is said to be and the more popular it gets the dirtier it gets. Relying upon a fallacy of indicating something bad isn't going to get you far in the future.Ôªø
author: John Klise

text:
@John Klise no irony. As electric cars and renewables become more popular, even the cars already on the road get cleaner over time. On a clean grid, like I think it's BC in Canada with lots of hydro, you could build and run 4 or 5 Tesla's for the same emissions as a single ICE vehicle over 180k miles.

When solar and wind are manufactured with solar and wind, and the cars are powered by it too, it'll be more like 10:1. And that ignores that batteries are built to be recyclable, and that GHG emissions are not the only thing that EVs do far better than current vehicles, especially diesel.Ôªø
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text:
Here in Australia, renewables are already reaching below what it costs to feed a coal plant, let alone build one, and that's with huge subsidies for mining and coal. Our renewable energy agency has said it's unlikely they'll do any more major subsidies past mid this year, as they are cheap enough to stand on their own.

India is pivoting to using its coal plants as firming power for renewables, rather than baseload. That means they are constructed to spin up and down quickly, rather than operate constantly at 'high efficiency', as if that is a term that can be applied to coal.Ôªø
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: @Matthew Jenkinson I get it dude, you are one of those crazy ass people who loves to portray electric cars as the best thing ever because you also enjoy sweeping everything bad about them under a rug.Ôªø
author: John Klise

text:
@John Klise no, I have just done enough reading to know that the environmental cost of manufacturing a battery and powering it with renewables is higher initially, but vastly lower over the life of the product. And according to the experts they can be mostly recycled.

You're welcome to show me using data where I'm wrong though.Ôªø

text:
Here are my complaints you didn't cover.
Incandescent headlights, the successor to the freaking candle on a $25k+ vehicle is ludicrous. No excuse for not coming with HID or LED headlights.
Lack of color. Dealer lots are a sea of black, white & silver. Mazda's red is stunning and that nice blue on the Tacoma looks great.
Heavy sound dampening including thick 'acoustic' glass. It adds performance killing weight!  Do I really need my car being soooo quiet?

Since you have a contact at Honda I would like to know WTF they were thinking about:
Delay valve on manual transmission clutch master cylinder. WHY? Dumbest shit EVER. MY 08 TSX was a nightmare to shift before I replaced the OEM CMC with a 2001 civic CMC without the valve. 
Another issue I hate is the ridiculously sensitive drive-by-wire throttle. 
Also when I take my foot off the throttle the engine cuts fuel, and there is an input lag when pressing the throttle again. I constantly have to pay attention to pressing the throttle well before releasing the clutch or the car will buck hard. Its annoying as F... and has made me realize the good ol days of fun to drive Honda are over.

Good job on getting over 1 million views in just 4 days on part 1...impressive
You must have struck a chord with the average car buying guy/galÔªø

author: Chris Zacho

text:
@ 3:04 - They don't use standard starters... they are engineered differently to account for the increased starter usage. They use a different gear-ratio to allow the starter to run at a lower RPM. They use different brushes (when brushes are used), they use needle bearings, they decouple the mechanical action from the electrical action of stopping and starting the motor, the ECM/PCM communicates with the starter and informs it when each cylinder reaches TDC. 

@ 10:53 - My old 95 T-Bird had a 4.6L V8 that ran about 2200 RPM at 70Mph, my new I-4 engine has a 6-speed transmission and runs at 2100-2200 RPM at 70Mph. Efficiency yes, but also the potential for reduced engine wear.

@13:19 - The areas that are't painted are those which are prone to paint chipping from rocks and debris. The primary purpose, aside from costs, is so you don't end up destroying the paint making it look terrible and also prevent rust from forming because some people don't realize how important proper paint care is. Some people buy these cars and drive down dirt roads, improperly maintained roads or simply roads that generally have alot of debris due to the amount/type of traffic that use them and this can help with future maintenance costs on the exterior.

The sterilization is real though... unfortunately it's the consumers that are directing this move based on their purchase decisions; Which is why is definitely won't go away anytime soon. Great video though, goes over alot of topics. Honestly I only wanted to mention the first thing about the starters because I've had many people ask about it. The starters are designed to handle the extra usage, however they are also more expensive to replace when they eventually fail. Also, having no oil dipstick is a dipshit thing to do... they really need to stop doing that... They CVT is an incredible implementation for a transmission, like you stated, the main issue that has been with CVT is manufacturers trying to cater to people by defeating its purpose to make it 'feel' like a regular transmission. I've own a car with a CVT and I absolutely loved how smooth it drove; Never driven a smoother car before or since.Ôªø

text: Although it's partly true, the black plastic cladding on today's vehicles is not to look rugged, but a design effect to reduce the overall mass of the vehicle. text:
LED bulbs of any type are unlikely to fail and need replacement for as long as you own our car. Here is a table I found of expected service life for different bulb types:
Incandescent = 750 to 1,000 hours
Halogen = 2,000 to 3,000 hours
Metal Halide = 7,500 to 10,000 hours
Fluorescent = 15, 000 to 20,000 hours
Mercury Vapor = 16,000 to 24,000 hours
High Pressure Sodium = 15,000 to 25,000 hours
High Power LEDs =35,000 to 100,000 hoursÔªø

author: Shane Tobin

text:
Just a thought: car buyers might not be so nitpicky if car makers offered more exciting choices in the first place. What's with Ford deciding that literally nobody wants to buy a sedan these days? Do we all want sucky SUVs and crossovers? Really? Car makers should be offering more choices, not fewer. Two door coupes used to be very popular, before the car makers raised the prices above 4 door sedans. Sedans and even station wagons are still popular in Europe. European cars also have noticeably better interiors and complain about American interiors. What's up with that? Do Americans really not care about how the interior looks, how the controls feel?

The other thing is that car buyers really can distinguish between real and fake. Why do car makers insist on putting fake stuff on their cars? Fake wood, fake carbon fiber, fake scoops and vents, fake floating roof, fake chrome, fake engine noise, fake CVT shifts, fake harsh sports suspensions, fake offroad capabilities? Why keep trying to fool the public into thinking that your car is something that it's not, or has a feature that it doesn't really have?Ôªø
author: dlwatib

text: These trends are a pain but a lot of them are necessary steps towards automation. Because of the cost to the manufacturers and consumers, cars cannot advance as quickly as other tech. If they don't diversify and embrace new tech, a lot of companies we've know forever will go away. Many barely held on after the last recession. We will probably see the final evolution of the current form within 30 years. After that we'll move on from even needing to own cars. Manufactures know that and are trying to stay ahead of the game. In the meantime, they need capital and will cater to the most common needs.Ôªø

author: Jeff Barnard

text: Jeff Barnard Because the dealer has to buy all the specialized equipment from the manufacturer in order to perform maintenance. That stuff costs thousands to tens of thousands of dollars. The dealer is also going to buy and use OEM parts from the manufacturer instead of cheaper (cost, not necessarily quality) aftermarket made parts. Also any time they can get you to go to the dealer and look at the shiny new cars is another opportunity to potentially sell you a new car as well.Ôªø

text:
Fake exhaust tips, fake engine sounds, No Nobs, Emissions tech, small engines instead of a properly sized NA V6/V8, tiny as all fuck factory Turbo's, Safety equipment, design in general, bloated vehicles, not as easy to work on, No factory boost guage or Boost controller, electronic parking brake,  factory exhaust systems, header integrated into the block, and much more.


Something I like but go too far:


Digital instrument cluster where I tend to like how it looks to a degree but if that screen goes your fucked. At least with the guages when they didn't light up they still worked and you could use a light to see them.


Electronic Power Steering is great when done right. I still heavily prefer Hydraulic but I'm tired of blowing Hydraulic lines from time to time. The main issue is the lack of road feel you get from EPS and the over complication it adds as a whole package with electronic everything else.


Not in most consumer cars yet but electrochromic glass is something I want to see more of but its also something that would be dangerous without a physical dial to change how dark it goes. Plus the minimum would need to be set at 5% otherwise some idiot would turn it down to the point they can't see. Then add the cost of it and to a degree weight it makes it hard to implement.Ôªø

text: All the "aids" and distractions.¬† Distracted driving is the #1 problem on the road today!!¬† There should be less "tech" or distraction promoting gizmos in cars.¬† Manufacturers are just loading cars up with shit to distract you, and then making the systems that will save you.¬† Blind spot warning, lane assist, radar controlled cruise control, automatic braking....etc.¬† If people would pay attention to the task at hand, namely driving, we would need none of this.¬† People need to quit being sheep to tech, and just get back to the basics of driving.¬† Frankly, I'm pissed that the manufacturers are enabling this, but I guess it is what sells.¬† I want my Honda S2000 back.¬† That was a driver focused car without all the crap, and as it should be.Ôªø

text: VIEWERS choose ,no how about us mechanics of the world that have to fix all this unnecessary useless engineering that they say the young people of the world wants .Which is not a true statement..by them.....In today's world of mechanics a technician has to really stay on top of his game if he wants to stay in this business .Everyone always like to say you guys are like doctors...The truth is that we do ,diagnosing the same but thats all...but for us ,a good Dealer tech has to be able to fix ----engines  transmission ,transfer case,s .rear ends , air bag systems .anti lock brake systems  digital air condition ,vehicle computer systems which may have as many as 13-20 different modules ,on star system ,collision avoidance system . Advanced infotainment system ,heads up display system ,so on and so on, Look most mechanic would rather be doing maintenance to  your vehicles  then trying to fix all this unneeded and in some cases unwanted technology that changes every year on us..Example , Cadillac has a 4 cylinder in it's new XT4 .  This little 4 cylinder has turbo charging , cam phaser .direct injection , Sliding camshaft technology ...Corvettes LT5 engine has a 16 digital fuel injection technology system along with ,digital active valve system ...O ya forgot hybrid technology cars and trucks .SO you get the point .Engineering is chasing the almighty M.P.G ,AND putting useless gadgets and gizmos in cars and trucks to keep us buy more ,more....So don't cry to the mechanics of the world when get big bill repairs ,you bought the car ,WE JUST HAVE TO FIX IT .THANKS MR ENGINEER .REMEMBER THE OLD SAYING KEEP IT SIMPLE STUPID.....THAT'S OUT THE WINDOW A LONG TIME AGO....Good luck with your next purchases.Ôªø

author: MrManiac3

text:
One aspect of all those SUVs is that you also can't see over them when you're riding a bike or a motorcycle. 10, 20 years ago I didn't need to peek out before overtaking a car, because you had all the road in your view. Drop a couple of cogs, pin it, you're done. Having a peek around an unnecessarily ginormous SUV on a motorcycle may be pretty dangerous, seeing how motorcycles are slower to steer than cars. Also, even if you peek out, you probably still are not seeing the side of the road before the car you're overtaking.
With a bicycle, the problem is even worse, because you're not visible to drivers in a line of cars. The front vehicle will cover you up entirely, and if it's an arsehole passing you too close, the driver behind you might not see you until the last second and possibly hit you. The cars need to get low again. Problem is, they won't unless technological constraints force them to, which is not gonna happen.Ôªø
author: horrovac

text: @horrovac -- Exactly. "Unnecessarily ginormous." Commercial vehicles are necessarily ginormous, but personal fatassmobiles are not justified except for families of more than 5. Choosing one is an act of rudeness toward other drivers. Those who drive SUVs, crossovers, and minivans interfere unnecessarily with the highway visibility of normal car drivers, and for many, their driving style seems to devolve into a rudeness appropriate to their choice of vehicle. Enforcing a left lane truck ban on highways for vehicles higher than 60 or 61 inches tall would discourage a lot of people from buying them, and might nudge carmakers to sell more wagons here that they currently sell overseas. And given the higher centers of gravity and the higher fatality rate in single-vehicle crashes of taller vehicles, keeping them out of the fast lane is justified on safety grounds.Ôªø

If I need to move a lot of stuff and/or tow a lot of stuff, I'm going to buy a pickup.

author: radiogreenblue

text:
Ok i call BS on the over generalizing SUV drivers. 

I drove my 2007 toyota Yaris Sedan for 11 years. a compact sedan for 11 fucking years. I'm 6' 2", i bang my head every time i got in and out, i bang my knees every time, my head hits the roof, i couldn't see signal lights because the windshield didn't go high enough. And i put up with that for 11 years.

After that I purchased a used RAV4. Not because of the "sports" stuff or off road or shitty fuel economy compared to my 35-40 mpg yaris, But I got it because it was roomier. SO fucking much more than my car. No more banging my head or knees. No more scraping the roof of the car with my scalp! I CAN FUCKING SEE THE SIGNAL LIGHTS NOW!!! 

Yes it's just a sedan with a station wagon body crammed on it, same 4 cylinder, same transmission, but thats what I wanted, I wanted a larger "car" I wanted something like my Yaris but just bigger!  Sure, the rav4 isn't an excursion or range rover or some monstrosity like a hummer, those I agree are worthless. But until they make an "oversized" sedan or a non-compact Sedan that i can comfortably sit in....I'll stick with my crossover.

And they're are plenty of people just like me.Ôªø

text: Car manufactures need to build infotainment units with free software updates.  I believe Tesla is the only manufacturer that is leading the way in this respect.  Car manufactures are missing an opportunity to keep the existing customers by not supporting them after they make a purchase. Auto makers are so used to disregarding a client after they buy a car.  They're only focus is on continually getting new customers.  But as car builders continue to in corporate more tech they will need to upgrade their products after a client makes a purchase.  Software grades are already common place to smart phones, printers, video cards, and cameras just to name a few. I just go a Mazda 2018 CX 5 and it does not have Android auto or Apple car play.  Mazda will retrofit their 2014 - 2018 vehicles with these apps for $443CDN.  This is a total slap in the a face to their current customers.  They reduce the price of the upgrade on their poorer selling vehicles like the Mazda 6. I would have been a lifetime Mazda customer if it made their software upgrade free and charged labour for installing a USB connector.  Now after signing the dotted line I feel like I am not being supported by Mazda like I would from a tech manufacture. I am sure Mazda is not the only auto company behaving like this and the auto industry needs to provide software upgrades as they continue to incorporate more tech in vehicles.Ôªø

author: The Fat Turtle

text:
This is the inevitable progression of any (and every) consumer-available technology. Early on it requires an enthusiast's level of dedication/mastery, then gradually becomes more and more broadly accessible as the challenging elements are refined. And right as the technology tips over from being predominantly something enjoyed for its challenge, engagement, or experience into something purchased for utility or status, the enthusiasts have a fit.

You see this throughout computing, as our workstations become disposable devices with soldered-on components and our application software become apps only obtained from a vendor-approved "App Store." And you're seeing it in automobiles, as cars become utilitarian status symbols and the idea of automotive pleasure or driving mastery becomes increasingly quaint‚Äîthere are constantly articles about how the next generation don't even seem interested in cars, preferring their smartphones and apps (maybe thus the LCD mania?).

I do wonder how many of these complaining "enthusiasts" put their money where their mouth is, though? Would they support a new entrant who built stripped-down, lightweight, mostly manual and capable vehicles? We may claim that there are simply more "mainstream" buyers than not, but I think even most enthusiasts are in name only‚Äîand I honestly can't blame them, because more and more of the places where most of us live are increasingly hostile to the car. To truly enjoy your car today, you have to live far enough away from a dense urban center that you're not constantly caught up in traffic, which limits jobs for most people. It's one hell of a catch-22.Ôªø

author: positron underVolt

text:
My complaints: 

1. Everything is smaller. Full size today is same size as my 2004 Durango mid size, although the seats are smaller with larger center consoles. This means myself at 6'5" is limited to older vehicles because I don't feel like laying down while I drive just to drive. Thus why I drive a proper truck, a 2006 Silverado. I try to avoid driving the wife's 2014 Pathfinder with its junk CVT whenever possible since my head sits too close to the ceiling, and have to be a contortionist just to get in and out.
2. Lack of manual transmission options. I understand everything is moving towards simplifying the driving experience, but also people are just lazy. It is too difficult to text and drive and shift and change the music at the same time. Again, I love the NV3500 in my Silverado. But if they want to make the fuel efficiency claim, my truck sees an average of 17 mpg city with the 5.3L V8, versus even newer automatic trucks are still below that.
3. Styling - everything these days looks the same, all the same eurotrash styles with minor variations that even Europeans don't want. This is why imports of older US vehicles to Europe is at a historic high.
4. No choice for baseline plain Jane no option versions. They're forcing these over complicated vehicles along with their extortion level pricing. Even the base model vehicles are so far beyond what is required for a simple vehicle. My 06 Silverado came with manual windows, manual transmission, am/fm radio, and literally no options. Radio has been upgraded with an aftermarket one but everything else is simple and plain, so much less to break and require replacement. Only exception is "fleet" trucks that are basic baseline, but no other vehicles offer that "no options" version.Ôªø

author: Jeremy Sims

text:
so, here is the thing with appealing to the "masses" they ruin good cars

looking at the mazda 3 now, part of the wave of good will that car has comes from people who like the drive etc, "it's a good car" from a car person means it feels nice to drive etc

honda made the same mistake 15~20 years ago with the civic, that was a drivers car, it's handling was on point, it was nimble, and great, the "masses" bought them in droves as car people loved them

then honda made the mistake that mazda is now, they listened too all those complaints, and forgot (I feel) to put them in context, that noise in the back, 
should be asked, of those people, "why did you get this car" and you'll find 9/10 they will have gotten it as they heard good things about it, they wont be able to really quantify anything tangible, but they know that is a louder from the back than they expected 

that should discount their view right there, simply as they are not buying the car for valid reasons, they are buying it on the solid recommendations of others, others who are not complaining 

and to repair a badge once it becomes nothing more than something that appeals to the masses is near impossible!, camry could be used as an example there,
or look at how far the civic fell, once those core USP's went, and all they were left was past glory, and marketing, the civic of new compared to contemporaries  can't hold its head up high like the mid 80's against its contemporariesÔªø

text: Alcantara steering wheels are actually super easy to clean. Just take a micro fiber cleaning cloth, dampen it with water and a touch of dish detergent, wring it out, and then grip the wheel with the cloth...wring your hand back and forth working along the entire circumference of the wheel, and presto! Looks like new. Do this at least twice a year and you're good to go. Nothing beats the feel of an alcantara wheel.Ôªø

text:
You can thank Ford Motor Company for that Jose C.
Ford designed the plastic composite headlight housings in the 1980's and claimed it increased visibility and safety and pushed the National Highway Safety Institute to require them on all vehicles by 1990 Chrysler Corporation and General Motors disagreed with Ford and said that the headlight housings would oxidize from the elements and heat of the bulbs and reduce light output Ford won and got their way.
Vehicles used to have glass sealed beam lightbulbs which didn't oxidize and was bright until broken or burned out and they were cheaper now you have the composite plastic headlight housings that cost hundreds of dollars to replace and the bulbs also cost between $50 & $100.Ôªø

author: vh x

text:
What manufacturers and consumers dont realize is that the NVH war was already fought before hand. All the snobs and grannies lost, because it wasnt a sustainable model to switch up all this stuff to please them.

Take the Quad 4 as a prime example. It was a wonderful motor, plagued by corporate decisions and bean counters. They used the wrong thickness head gasket despite the engineers' wishes, they decided on a horrid oil system that created the pancake batter effect in early motors, that was later revised. And then, they decided to bog it down by adding more and more plastic garbage to please the grannys who complained that it was 'too noisy'. They kept the high power Quad 4 cars in a seperate catagory until 95', but ended up screwing themselves by continuing the noise dampering on the motor. They added .1 liter, balanced shafts, and an absolute nightmares worth of plastic to the intake, and released the 2.4L Twin Cam. Its still a great motor, but it was the quietest and most tame of the engine family to date. In order to really wake it up, youd have to remove all the plastic, and add a custom setup. They basically hushed the engine to make sure granny jenkins was happy. The ecotech went though the same ordeal. And not it has so much plastic on it that it may as well be a fisher price toy.

If manufacturers listened to its real customers and supports, instead of the press and pristine pricks that wouldnt know a good driving experience from a golf cart,  I may have bought a new car by now. But with all the useless and overcomplicated bullshit on cars these days, I wont ever touch one. Like my grandfather always said: if you own it, you better know how to fix it. And I have no desire to fix a mess of expensive plastic powered by computers. 


Thanks for covering this geese.Ôªø

text: Well Mitch, that doesn't surprise me. They don't want an easy or cheap fix because they don't make a shit ton of money off of us. author: Matthew Cowan

text:
My 1st Accord (my CB7 / 92). the bulbs could be changed pretty easily. My 2nd Accord (my '00) was pretty much the same (front and back). My 3rd Accord.. ('05) had done away with replacing bulbs THAT EASILY, the rear ones.. were still pretty easy.

My 4th Honda, My 05 Element... needs the front clip removed.. to change a bulb. Rears can be done in 5min.

Who.. actually figures out.. that to remove a blown bulb.. ya have to remove the front of the car...

What idiot failed Engineering school with that idea.

Im still pissed off.. that cars dont have a simple electrical thing built into their lamps n wiring...

Equallying a fuse. If a Lamp blows.. ya see a sign of it in the dash.. or ya hear it double blinking...


Oh THATS RIGHT....
Every dash is going towards A SCREEN.. what bullshit.

P.S
Last night... I dropped my keys.. and the back half of my Fob.. which predates it being a part of the key.. popped out with the battery atrached.

I popped it back in, I tapped LOCK.. ONCE and lights flashed (as I heard my lock solinoids engage. (As they should, two taps would sound horn.. I hate hearing peoples horn.)Ôªø

text: Not to be pedantic, but the very first cars ever made were electric. The first electric carriages were made in the 1830s, but the first practical petrol car was made by Daimler Benz in the 1880s. In a sense, electric cars are old technology brought up to date with the present.Ôªø
