text: As an engineer I will promise you start stop starters are not the same as your typical 12v starters. Also... the start stop has no effect on engine wear. Once the engine warms up the start stop feature will turn on and there is no effect on engine wear.Ôªø
author: paladain55

text:
It actually saves quite a lot of fuel especially in city conditions....And I really think the hate should be directed towards bad start-stop systems, rather than all of them as a whole, as they can be made to function well.  
The increased wear is a common misconception, as there is literally no engine wear since your oil and coolant are already at operating temps. Starter motor wise, even if it were to use the same starter, most people aren't going to keep their car for more than 5 years so it doesn't matter, same story with the battery.  
BTW If you really don't want to wear down your engine, then never do a cold start, as you are hurting it the most every morning you start it up.Ôªø
author: stoneee1234

text:
Chaos Corner
I like the Automatic Start Stop Engine System in my BMW, it also calculates, learns and depends on various factors when it actually turns off the engine. Example in a traffic jam with many stop and go situations it learns that the standing times are too short so it doesn turn off the engine instantly unless more time passes it dynamically reacts to the conditions.
Start Stop is always on but you can temporaly turn it off pressing the A button above Start Stop.
Also, on a manual Auto Start Stop can only apply and turn off the engine when you are in neutral gear.Ôªø

text:
People are getting more stupid. It might sound wrong because we have all the informations in our pockets but just because we can easily get important and correct information doesn't mean we do. It shows with our car choices. My friend just lost the battle with his wife aver a car. They've bought Ford Kuga and I asked them why. They said it's good family car and it can go offroad. I've said that it has front wheel drive only and the same ground clearence as my quattro but less space inside so let's have a competition, they didn't want to because the most important argument for the Kuga was that the wife liked the looks of it. That's all there is to SUV's, they are fashion items and people buying them like those stupid pants that looks like denim but they have a rubber on the end of the legs... My other friend bought 5 years old Audi last year. He was so proud because it is such a good looking car with very economical and yet quite lively diesel. But then one day he was in a supermarket car park and he pressed "hand" brake button a few times in a row and the brake stuck in locked because the button stopped working. He had to leave the car there for the night. The next day guy came with a computer and set the car free... I mean to the servis. 
I don't know much about electronics but in my opinion it doesn't last forever without issues. Especially in cars where it shakes and gets cold, hot or wet. It has to be light, compact and cheap with lots of features to please the customer who's gonna pay for it all again in the future.Ôªø

author: Dave ThaBoss

text: From a mechanics point of view, thank you!!  The electronic parking brakes should be illegal.   They are a safety issue pure and simple and if you've ever run into one that's stuck on, it's a bear to get it off the rotor just to move the car; same thing with the "Electronic shifters."  Lose power or have a gear selector malfunction you can't even push/move the car.  On the BMW's you have to jack up the car, remove all the belly pans and run an allen bolt into a lever and force the transmission into neutral.  On the Mercedes it's even worse.  They have a module mounted to the side of the transmission.  You have to pull the belly pans, fight the module off the side of the transmission and you can just barley reach behind it and fish a tool onto the selector shaft and put the trans in neutral.  "Features" like these are no longer features.  They're solutions to problems that didn't exist and cause more failures.  It's a sad state in the automotive world right now especially for the vehicle's owner.Ôªø

text:
There are two valid reasons smaller SUVs, etc., have become very popular with consumers & it is to do with seat-height; parents find it easier to secure their young children into safety-seats, & the other is that the aging baby-boomer population are now finding it more difficult to access lower vehicles if they're on the tall side!
However, these are the sort of drivers who can well do without the distraction & expense of over-complicated tech (my parents wanted the comfort, but struggle with the sat-nav), & interiors need to be resilient enough to withstand rug-rats & teenagers without the only choice nasty no-frills budget models!Ôªø

author: professorquack

text: First off, I'm going to make a distinction between a real SUV, and a crossover, 90% of the "SUV's" currently on the road, are in fact, crossovers, not SUV's. An SUV is a Truck underneath, with a full frame, a solid rear axle, leaf springs, torsion bars, big ground clearance. It can go offroad, it can haul trailers, etc. Most of these things are crossovers, they are for all intents and purposes overgrown station wagons with slightly more ground clearance, they have unibody construction etc. Because the manufacturers realize 90% of the people buying these things will never actually go off road or haul anything heavy, and that all these people really care about is fuel economy and cargo capacity. As for why the hate, because people like me who prefer to drive a car most of the time, that doesn't have shit handling for extra cargo capacity, that I could get just as easily in a wagon, we get sick of not being able to see anything in front of us because there's always someone in a crossover in front, and 90% of the time, there is no need for it and they are just taking up space and reducing visibility of the people who don't want to get on the crossover bandwagon, I bet half these people only own a crossover so they can see past all the other fucking crossovers. I honestly don't know wtf these people don't just buy wagons, they handle better and hold as much if not more cargo.Ôªø

text:
With the addition of digital displays all over the place, the automakers can infinitely customize and quickly create/add features. Those features translate as marketing points to boost sales.
Not hating or loving this - just saying because that is exactly what my company's touch screens are: operation, information, features, more features, more marketing potential, more sales.
At the end of the day, the innumerable features create massive complexity. Complexity is the enemy of reliability.
We can make a difference: change the opinion of people, change the sales picture, change the automobile.Ôªø

author: Horizon585

text:
These companies don't make cars to make people happy - they have to continually improve profits year over year.

The market got saturated with good cars that would last a long time and leave the customer satisfied. So the next logical step once everyone who could buy a car had one was to artificially increase the price of the car by non-optional addons, cumbersome or proprietary maintenance routines, and engineered obsolecence.

How can a company whose only requirement is to maintain a profit make any other choice? If customers left fully satisfied, the customer would never come back and consumers aren't being born as quickly as they used to be. Every customer has to be a return customer. That's why businesses are merging or failing and why wealth is centralizing. If you want profit to define value, then the consumer market must be squeezed dry, because the falling rate of new births and rising rate of jobs taken over by robots aren't reversing any time soon. Everything must be disposable if a business wants to fill its available market and not then immediately collapse.

We had a good run for so long because the babies were booming out and the country was transitioning from poor and rural to rich and urban. That growth is never happening again.Ôªø

text:
Okay, I have to say something abou the start/stop thingy. 
I have a '12 1series, where, of course, you can easily deactivate this with the button over the start button. 
I live in a rural area in Germany and sometimes road works and closings require traffic lights to be set up. 
So coming to a stop on one of these I know I am going to stand there for at least a minute. And then the start/stop makes absolutely sense. 
Of course, if you live in a larger city and come to a stop every minute, it's just stress for the mechanical parts. 
So when the car is still cold I deactivate it and reactivate it once I know I will come to a halt shorty.Ôªø

author: ClayZ

text:
I just came upon your channel a few days ago and it‚Äôs refreshing to see others that feel the same as I do. Growing up in the 80‚Äôs I remember thinking how cool it was when I got my fist electronic dash on my Cutlass supreme and the cool shaped ‚ÄòPlastic‚Äô everything inside and out of my new 94 Z-28 with the LT1. I was working as a crew member for a National Airline and  I could not wait until what was next.  Now I hate all of it !

 I don‚Äôt need a electronic device to tell me that I need air in my tires for example. It‚Äôs just one more thing that can go wrong and cost a lot of money to fix,  otherwise you got to sit there and look at the blinking light on your dash.  They really are looking more and more like  cockpits of an Airbus and spacecrafts. That‚Äôs the trend today that the generation wants and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre stuck with. Or, if you‚Äôre lucky like I was.  Buy a car that‚Äôs about 10 years old (One owner, garage kept, very low mileage)  that has  just about enough technology in it to make it enjoyable to ride and keep it up.   Use to be that in America things were built to last and they did,  but slowly we became a disposable society.  If you remember when gas grills were all the rage and now you can get one for 100 bucks and within a year or two it‚Äôs rust and you toss it out. This is now becoming a trend with cars really. Cars are becoming disposable as we  become a more disposable society.  Thank you for the great videos you are making !Ôªø

You're in for a treat. I recommend watching all his videos (starting from like 3 years ago). He just keeps getting better and better, and is literally one of the only enthusiasts I trust with advice or other knowledge. The endless random humor and dry wit is an extra bonus.Ôªø
author: Aleks Ulmer

text:
I guess different strokes for different folks. 

My first car was also an Cutlass Supreme with a digital dashboard. I loved it. Said it had ‚ÄúEFIS‚Äù. I went through to a VW GTI (terrible car) and then into family vehicles of various age and boringness until I bought a 2018 Honda Civic hatch. 

Although I bought a rare manual transmission version and it has no assists other than ABS, VSC, and a backup camera, I love it. I love its electronic instrument panel with gas and temp resembling the old Cutlass and the rendered analog tach surrounding the digital speed readout. I like the infotainment that allows me to connect with my phone and music. It feels just like when I went into my Proline 21 cockpit after decades of flying steam gauges... everything was clear and tons of information was available. 

There‚Äôs a couple things I don‚Äôt like. No volume knob... but I use the steering wheel anyways. No climate control... but one buttton brings it back and it‚Äôs usually on auto anyways. 

But overall... I‚Äôm really happy with the level of technology I have.Ôªø

author: Justin Noker

text: One other thing I just thought of that I think is incredibly stupid - integrated headlight/turn signal. Most cars do it this way, which means that when the headlight is on it's hard to see the turn signal. This has been common for a while, but getting worse as headlights get smaller and more intense, the module smaller thus the lights closer together. What's the obvious solution? Separate them by a few inches. But do car makers do the logical thing? NEVER! Instead they wire it to turn off the headlight when the turn signal is on. Works I suppose, but is that really the best solution? Car makers love to find the most complex solution possible.Ôªø

text:

Also poorly placed turning signal i.e. bottom of vehicle. Just poor lighting in general.Ôªø
author: Jose M. Molina Ocampo

text: Exactly. In my opinion the best arrangement is on the old Bug, which had the headlight on the front of the fender and the turn signal on top, fairly far from and above the headlight, so glare isn't really an issue. I'm one who tends to see the Bug as having the best solution to almost everything. This wouldn't really work so well on a newer vehicle, as they don't have fenders to put them on top of, and just putting them on the sides of the hood would look hideous - as seen on the Toadmobile (which Nissan refers to as the Juke). I can't think of a particularly good place to put them on more modern cars, probably best is low down below the headlights - not as optimal, but at least it's not right next to the headlight. Maybe low down, but also have some beside the headlights visible from the sides, and on the mirrors - that's very visible from an oncoming direction and plenty far from the headlights, without looking terrible.Ôªø

The combination of poor¬†self-awareness¬†and low cognitive ability leads them to overestimate their own capabilities. author: Varun Sambi

text: Glad you caught that grill thing - looks so hideous, makes the cars look brutish and inelegant. Toyota's latest styling, adding to this an excessive jaggedness. As for the complexity of engines, we're in the awkward last hurrah of gasoline powered cars, we all know the future is electric - which is much simpler in every way. Thus it will get better, but not in simplifying gas engines. That will likewise eliminate the transmission entirely. I think it's really silly when a new technology eliminates the need for this or that, but it's still kept because consumers are used to it - if you're using new tech, roll with it, flaunt it, don't hide it! This is true for the "shift points" on a CVT, as well as fake blocked-off grills on electric cars. On that note, would it be possible to make a manual CVT, instead of having notches one puts the gearshift into they can slide it fore and aft or something to change the ratio, without having to use a clutch - I think that could make for some interesting driving techniques. Either mechanically actuated, or electronic but with the driver controlling instead of ECU. As for the smaller windows - how could that make something "safer?" Maybe better protection in a collision, but I'd rather be able to see so that I don't get in the collision in the first place! That's harder to quantify than HNTSA/NCAP ratings, and I think people are too quick to just consider the number of stars rather than big picture. I get a sense that it's more a matter of styling.Ôªø

But no, i press windshield defog, blower goes almost highest every time, i turn AC/Heat off, it turns fresh air to circulation, because devs are thinking consumer probably don't want "any" air. For some weird reason my vehicle always switch air to circulation after engine start and also every time i turn on AC from OFF because devs probably think i want cool air the fastest way. author: Sean Taylor

text:
@Rey Arthur 
I can't believe they are doing these shenanigans re: brakes JUST to make it harder on the DIY mechanic! What a bunch of dicks!

It reminds me of the complicated keys of today's cars. In the old days, it cost $5 or less to have a duplicate key cut. Now, it cost anywhere from $35 - $100 because the duplicate key must contain the silly 'transponder' which is embedded in the key.

This transponder must 'shake hands' with the matching 'transponder' that exists in the steering column/near the key hole. Sure, this makes it harder for thieves to copy a key... but if a thief REALLY wants to steal your vehicle, not having a key is just a minor formality!Ôªø
author: Andy Roid

text:
@Andy Roid I actually think the transponder thing is great. What is not great is having to go through the dealer and get OEM keys if you need another one. They should be required to allow aftermarket keys and make it easy to add them to the car or do the programming for free.


I think the latter is blocking the former since you know the Chinese would be churning out compatible blanks by the million if they were easy to add to our cars.Ôªø

author: RD

text:
@Cassidey Ousley Away from talking drive engagement and raw practicality:
Complication, servicing cost and longevity.

Manual gearboxes usually outlive multiple engines. The Smart's automatic slushbox only had a designed lifespan of 100,000km. My dad was building them and said they were a crap design internally.

CVTs need regular belt replacements, old automatics need regular oil changes and wear internal clutches. 
If they go wrong, too complicated and expensive to repair.
Just watch EricTheCarGuy's trial to rebuild the Honda Odyssey gearbox.

Most automatics can't be towed and you can't push start them if the battery is troubles.

That's why you see more old manuals still running.Ôªø

author: Cassidey Ousley

text:
Oh my the comments.
Driving manual is not hard and isn't just and enthusiast thing, seriously. 
It's like walking and chewing gum at the same time.

@Those that don't see a problem with having reduced longevity. 
Are you guys made of money?
New cars a ridiculously expensive and you think its fine that it's ok if 50,000$ (that's just a spec'ed up Honda Odyssey) turn to dust in just 5 years?
Don't you think cars would be more accessible if they were more affordable and would retain their value better?

@BMW dude: great for you that you can afford a modern state of the art gearbox. Good luck though if ever anything goes wrong as they're not cheap to fix. Just the clutch mechanism on a DSG alone will cost you dearly if you ever burn it or wear the plates out as many come as unserviceable assembled units.

Also, not all gearboxes are made the same. The original Smart was a slushbox that took forever to change gears. I've recently had the pleasure of driving a Canter truck with Duonic DSG gearbox and boy, was that a pile of junk. It was so slow to change gears it almost came to a stall going up some hills in Brisbane. I couldn't imagine that thing in a place like San Francisco. The clutch engagement was terrifying when trying to turn this thing around in a tight space as it couldn't engage the clutch smoothly. It reminded me of the Saab James May tried to park with its semi automatic gearbox.

I don't hate automatics, I ride a semi automatic CUB and love the design.  Simple centrifugal clutch with predictable engagement, very reliable, compliant to use and simple mechanical design tied to a strong sequential gearbox.

However, most cars nowadays are overly complicated in their design. You often end up fighting the gearbox when trying to get it to do what you want it to do. Why do we need so many darn drivemodes?

Example: Subaru's Forester is crippled when going offroad by its gearbox management and you need to use settings that are against the manufacturer recommendations to successfully climb hills some hills.Ôªø

text: I am surprised to say this myself, but probably the best trend with some new cars is the Simplicity of electricity. Not that it has been done properly as yet, as I have heard that the only moving part in Tesla's frequently needs to be replaced, maybe every 50,000 miles or less. However, I test drove the Tesla Model S and was shocked at the performance of the electric engine it was awesome. I must say the interior of the Tesla was also clean modern and excellent. And I'm not a Tesla Fanboy, I'm just saying it as it is. Then I thought about it after I drove it, I said to myself all you got here is a bunch of batteries and an electric motor or two. Getting rid of the internal combustion engine reduces complexity, and should make for a much simpler vehicle, and more reliable. You don't have to worry about exhaust pipes or gasoline or changing the oil or adjusting the valves or getting a new timing belt etc etc. So, electric cars have incredible potential to simplify cars and actually increase their performance. And again I'm an old V8 guy and I love internal combustion engines but I can appreciate the potential Simplicity of electricity.Ôªø

What‚Äôs more complex?  A turbo, wastegate, and an intercooler... big deal. What‚Äôs less reliable?  Still fewer moving parts than a V6‚Äìlots of which are getting one or two turbos, too.

author: WhateverNevermind

text:
Mechanic here, I can tell you most of these trends are because our idiot generation z. Drivers aid, T/C and ABS are because they are too stupid to put their phone down and need help stopping. Fwd fwd is useless, you can steer out of almost any street skid with a rwd. With young dumb kids, mostly women. I have seen that they get into a skid mid winter and don't have the skill to correct. Even though fwd is point the wheels away from the object you're about to hit, and floor it catch traction. You'll have a shitty body roll jerk, but no fucked up car. 

As for the other complaints people have, well that you can blame yourself on. Because a majority pushes for eviromental control (1 Prius = 10, 3500 dodge dualies emmissions) ice engines won't be V8's much longer which is retarded. We already got rid of I6 engines. Why is it bad we get rid of race inspired engines? Because the reliability of customer cars goes down. I own a Silverado (6.2L), a elantea gt sport (1.6T), and have a 2J being built on a stand for the elantra. Why swap an engine 1 year into ownership? Emissions make the gdi engines fill up the cylinder bores with carbon, and the maintenance to keep the 1.6 running for 5 years is the same for a 2j swap, rwd conversion with custom tube work for the front and read subframes. 
We need to have some mechnics design the cars from now on. Fuck engineers, they are the retards who make everything fit just barely. Yet since they are engineers youd thunk they are smart enough to either remove uneeded drivera aids, or reposition some components to make everything fit. 


Worst design ive seen for a so called simple repair on most cars. Clutch master cylinder on any genisis coupe. You need to remove the drive shaft, 2 motor mounts, angle the engine down and trans remove the trans, then go to the rear of the car to remove the master cylibder which is also up and to the left of the rear diff. After getting to the cylinder you need to remove 3 bolts and struggles usijg different angles to remove the part. 

Fucking why, why not just put the master cylinder next to the BMC? Its how i set up all my race cars. 


Thank you for destroying something you know nothing about. (Directed towards women and liberal men)Ôªø

author: Ray Jimenez

text: One of the biggest problems these days is that all cars are hideously ugly. Almost without exception. Look down the line of Lexus or BMW or Audi or any of the others and you may lose your lunch. Audi's a little better than the others but they're so gland and so kitschy as to be unacceptable. There's too many gimmicks and add-ons that manufacturers use inside and out to make people think that the car is incredible. So, the number one worst thing these days is styling or the lack thereof. The second worst thing is ergonomics. So many factors are starting to get this right such as Porsche with their touch screens which are excellent, but Lexus across the line continues with the worst design of ergonomics in the history of modern man. I own a Lexus, so I really know this to be the case. The third worst thing these days is that you cannot purchase a car with a manual transmission. There are many Enthusiast out there like myself that would prefer in most cases to drive a car with a manual transmission. There is nothing like a manual transmission, and a PDK or one of those other newfangled automatics are not the same. I'm talking about a manual transmission with the clutch pedal. The force major drawback to cars these days is what you mentioned, way too much Electronics! Nobody can work on these cars anymore because you pop open the hood and all you see is a giant big piece of plastic and underneath that there is a million vacuum tubes and electrical lines and just a complete disaster and cluster bang of nonsense. I long for the days when I could pop open my hood and I could change the spark plugs super easy, I could do basic work like change the thermostat Etc no longer!Ôªø

author: Nick Name

text:
I love my 2001 Jeep Cherokee. No Abs, stability system...manual parking brake , 4 speed automatic that always is in the right gear and shifts instantly with no hesitation. Excellent outward visibility, rugged painfully simple drivetrain that is both easy and cheap to repair by any mechanic. The straight six with an iron block is from the ice age. Response is instant ...no turbo.... no stop start just instant torque. 
I do not like having my family in the Cherokee. Aside from being very solid it just is not a safe car. .......so........ in about 10 days I am buying the safest car money can buy. I am still keeping the Jeep. 

My new car will hit 60 in under 5 seconds. It has excellent handling and steering feel. It has room for  four 6 foot + people. 

It also has the black piano trim, electric parking brake and a big screen in the center of the dash. A stability system that can‚Äôt be turned off. 

I drove it and I love it. Excellent vision all around ( save the rear view). In spite of being the safest car on the road. Instant torque like nothing else I have experienced with only a 1 speed transmission. 

Every thing that is wrong with most modern cars Tesla somehow got right. So like 108,000 people before me and over half a million people still waiting for a sedan  .... not an Cuv. I am getting a Tesla 3. 

I won‚Äôt be saving the world quite yet ( I think the Cherokee and the 3 cancel each other out).Ôªø

text: It's because the manufacturers are now selling "safety" instead of driving dynamics, and ya know, we can just NEVER be safe enough, so lets just keep complicating things as much as possible.   From my perspective, if the cars were simply more engaging/fun to drive, then people would be more into it, rather than just seeing it as a nuisance looking for a form of distraction while on the way to punching in on that 9-5 job.  You also must address the mental health issues we have in this country:  People are plugged in constantly to their phones that predominantly serve to sell fear/distraction, and now we have fear based consumerism combined with distracted driving, and we "wonder" why there's more crashes resulting in death, so, lets just buy bigger "safer" vehicles like SUV's / CUV's = safety arms race = higher cost/worse vehicles to drive.   You know what:  I love my 370z, yet, everyone (even Z owners) complain all day long about how it needs to be "more refined" etc.   THEN, we look back:  "I wish we had a Z that was more engaging to drive" <---- will be the review of the new Z in 2020.  So it's a no win, and predominantly the masses want living rooms on wheels because they have bought into the fear based marketing, not to mention:  Americans are as OBESE as ever, so you have people that want physically larger vehicles so they don't "feel" as fat as they really are. author: thatallredheadude 1

text:
I think it was a bit further back than that.  Both my Camry and my wife's E320 are 1998 models.  Her E320 has an electronic key and try as I might, I have been unable to find a remote-start system compatible with her car.  My Camry (a hand-me-down from my wife) has a remote start alarm I installed shortly after we bought it.  Physical, metal key.

On the other hand, both of our cars have backup cameras, dashcams, upgraded stereos, and upgraded brakes.  My wife's even has bluetooth in her new stereo.  What happened to DIN and double-DIN openings for stereos in car dashboards?  What happened to separate, distinct controls for HVAC, radio, wipers, etc.?

The average age of automobiles on the road in America now is about 11 years. Technology moves so fast and new advances keep coming out, but the auto makers are now making it harder and harder for owners of older vehicles to upgrade their vehicles to keep up with modern technology, some of which is safety related.

I also agree with the always-on instrament illumination and the vehicles going down the street at night with their lights off. This one started with luxury and high-end Vehicles going back 20 years or so. If you're going to put an always-on instrument cluster in a vehicle, the lights have to be fully automatic, just because they're so many mindless zombies on the road pretending to be drivers.

That's another pet peeve of mine. there are far too many mindless zombies on the road who do not want to drive a car, truck, SUV, or any other vehicle, but feel that they must to be able to get from point A to point B. For them driving is a necessary evil and they would much rather spend their time on their smartphone then actually paying attention to the road and traffic around them while they're sitting in the driver's seat of a 4000 pound missile traveling down the road.

Ugh!Ôªø

As cars become more "computer-like" they will also start to need software updates that might stop comming one day, or might have security or performance issues, so the life cycle is shorter. As a result, the cars will feel old and need to be replaced a lot sooner then the good old mechanical ones. And that couldn't be better for the manufacturers.Ôªø
author: Richard Kalaf

text: RENILO  I‚Äôm not saying they aren‚Äôt reliable for  5 or so years.  If you  change out every couple of years this conversation is moot.  For those of us who keep their vehicles for decades you will be hard pressed  keeping a late model car beyond the warranty without going broke.  It seems the Germans were a decade ahead of the curve as you can see by the lack of value  due to  the expensive maintenance.Ôªø
author: Scott G
RENILO

text: @RENILO  You should consider yourself one of the few lucky Mercedes owners of that era that hasn't spent well more than the car is worth fixing some of he more problematic bugaboos the E-class is know for. First and foremost the atrocious Airmatic suspension or many of the electrical ghosts that live in the wiring harness.    I'm curious about the history of the car if don't mind me asking.   I typically find older well maintained cars from dry climates that have been garaged their entire life then to be less problematic.Ôªø
author: Scott G

text: ‚Äã@Scott GThe car was bought in Norway late 2003 has no  airmatic suspension and around 245,000KM on it, no idea who the original owner was, however, the previous owner drove it to Poland and back a few times and he seems to have taken good care of it. it's been winter driven on salted icy roads and somehow has little to no rust apart from a few rock chips which I'm working on atm. My buddy has a C-class from 2004 or 05 diesel which is also only had maintenance parts changed. It's all about looking after your car and then any car can be reliable.Ôªø
author: RENILO

text: @RENILO I'm impressed as they can start to have have electrical issues by 175 k km  (100k miles) in wetter climates. Be glad you don't have the Airmatic, it's expensive junk and I've replace a few with spring conversions, which alleviate the problem but still require some computer antics to fool the system into thinking it's still there.   Here in the western US  I find most Mercedes do we'll  if they are kept garaged along with proper scheduled maintenance.  They do not like heat that's for sure.  The interiors, rubber and plastics  just get destroyed. It's quite common to find low mileage cars in excellent mechanical condition but they are cosmetically not worth buying even for 3 or 4k.    Good luck and enjoy your classic E-Class.Ôªø

author: TEDdotcom

text: @Justin Noker public transportation stays mostly in larger cities because the people in suburbs and rural areas have varying schedules and destinations therefore making it extremely unfeasible for it to survive outside of major metropolitan areas. Also, it is rather "anti-freedom" to consider that a person's work schedule and social life should become dependant upon a bus or train schedule. Also, if while on the way back from a store, if a forgotten item is remembered, it's a lot easier to turn a car around versus a bus or train.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text: @Steve Thornton don't forget that their domestic car lineup makes public transport look like a stylish ride.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text:
@Travis Smith then how does Europe do it? They have regularly scheduled busses and trains that go through suburban areas. Sure it's understandable having nothing between 10PM and 6 AM, but from there they're pretty regularly scheduled based on what my European friends tell me. You get on a bus that comes at most every 20 minutes, catch a train, and then you can go anywhere from there. Your schedule doesn't revolve around the transit tables, as they run that frequently. 
A good local example is the town I live in has a train line with an Amtrak service that goes by it. If we had even a bad bus service to European standards (every 30 minutes) and a train station on the CSX mainline that the Amtrak runs on, nobody would need a car here, everybody could easily get to the city. That's how they do it in Europe.Ôªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker I would assume massive subsidies from more socialistic gov't systems. In America, why would we pay more in taxes for public transportation when we pay good money for tags and insurance on our personal vehicles that can take us where we want when we want. At least if I leave 5 minutes late for work, I won't have to wait another 15-25 minutes for the next train/bus.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text: @Travis Smith that is true, they are more taxed, but it could be argued that the extra benefits they receive justifies the extra taxation. And you think they don't have the same situation there with their personal vehicles too? Of course they still can own their own cars, and many do. But for those that can't afford them or choose not to drive, public transport is always there for ya. And for the "late to work" thing, of you're already late what's an extra 15 minutes? Plus if you miss the bus, that's still your own fault for not leaving early enough.Ôªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Jon M I used to have a 1 hour commute for 6am shift and we had a bus that drove the workers because the company ran out of parking space. Its possible but americans just dont want itÔªø

text: @Jon M I live in a 800 inhabitant village. The bus collected people from my village  and  other small  towns  and drove 45min to a urban area where my workplace wasÔªø
author: totoIV

text: @Justin Noker the problem with having taxes pay for public transportation is that if you don't use it, you're being taxed for nothing. If a person pays for their tags and registration, that money goes for the infrastructure. That is more of a fair tax. As to my point of leaving 5 minutes late, being 5 minutes late out the door doesn't automatically mean late for work. However if a person has to wait another 15-25 minutes, that would probably make them late for their shift.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text:
@Travis Smith well what difference does it make from your current taxes being used on the roads even if you live in the city and don't own a car? Cause that's the current situation yet nobody complains about that.

And again, point still stands, your fault still for leaving late. Not the busses fault you missed itÔªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker yes, my taxes go to infrastructure. However, even if I didn't have a vehicle, I would still be benefitted by the infrastructure. Everything from items being delivered to my residence to the ability for emergency services to render aid would be my tax dollars at work. And back to the bus schedule bit once again, by not being dependant on a bus I'm free to leave when I want. I can arrive as early as I want or get somewhere just in time. It's my choice. That's a freedom that I wish to keep and exercise regularly.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text:
@Travis Smith and how are you not benefited by public transportation? for one it helps save on fuel, as more people that take it, the less demand there will be for fuel, and the cheaper it could potentially get then. and for a train, you would get benefits there from reliable out-of-town travel for distances generally too far to drive. and again, as I said, when a bus comes regularly, again, you still have this freedom. it's just in intervals.

Also, when did I ever say I wanted to see all cars taken off the road in place of public transit? never. just simply saying that a reliable public transportation network would make many people second guess their need for a car, which can lead to cost savings in the form of not needing registration or insurance payments anymore (or even car payments, which these days are getting to be the price of a year long transit pass in some places). I also want to point out that it isn't so much a freedom to travel wherever you want, but more of a luxury. when not everyone can do it, that's all it is, a luxury. public transit actually gives people the freedom to travel around regardless of income.Ôªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker first off, I'm not benefitted by public transport because there isn't any close enough to make a difference. Secondly, never in this conversation have I suggested that you're for the abolition of personal vehicles. And lastly, it isn't a luxury to be able to go where I want when I want. It is a freedom that I have earned. It goes back to the saying that "freedom isn't free". If one doesn't want such responsibility that grants such a freedom, let them be handcuffed to public transportation and taxis and such services.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text: @Travis Smith what I was saying was the potential benefits you could have from it. i didn't suggest you had it. and yes, it is still a luxury. most of the world isn't like the U.S. where we think cars are essential for freedom where public transport covers their needs just fine and they're just as free. it's the same case with healthcare. most other civilized countries have dealt with it, just by being alive you have the freedom to receive medical care paid by your taxes, so you can afford it no matter what. in the U.S., healthcare isn't a right, it's a luxury. this is the same case as that.Ôªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker and once again, you mention something that is another tax drag that governments screw up. Government should not be in the health insurance game. The last group of people I want in charge of whether or not I should have a procedure done is politicians. If you're okay with that, have fun in your "socialist utopia". The government only has a small amount of things that it should do. When you have a group that can give you everything you want or need, you have a group that can take it away.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith

text: @Travis Smith so when people that legitimately couldn't afford a hospital stay (such as me) end up needing to go to the ER, you'd rather want to see us die? Also when did I ever say I was a socialist? This here is literally part of the problem of America, suggest higher taxes to implement some changes to increase quality of life even for the poorest of citizens, and you're labeled a socialist. I'm done here.Ôªø
author: Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker as a parting note, I never called you a socialist. I merely stated that government trying to provide what citizens should provide for themselves is socialist.Ôªø
author: Travis Smith
Justin Noker

text: @Justin Noker rather long-winded for being done. The problem with socialist programs is that when implemented, it becomes argued that it isn't enough. Afterwards, people beg for the gov't to do more and more. Rather than having a gov't agency provide charity, it is far more appropriate for an actual charitable organization to provide charity. They normally have less corruption and are less wasteful with their resources. I've seen many charitable organizations help less fortunate people with cars (acquisition and repairs). As far as health insurance, most employers provide plans as a benefit. I've seen some of the best and worst in the different jobs that I've held. I have even left jobs for better benefits. The worst thing that has happened has been the ACA. It actually raised my plan cost because of the regulations. It's another sign of how horrible socialist programs are that the majority of people are made to suffer to help well less than 10% of the population.Ôªø

text: @neoabraxas Nope, adding the plastic panels does not keep the metal they're on from rusting.  It just means that when that metal does rust, you have less structural stability because automakers are now using thinner steel and elaborate shapes to provide the unibody stiffness.   The best thing you can do to combat rust, is get a truck with a full frame.  At least then it is structurally sound for a while.  I too live in a harsh rust zone and have retired cars because they simply could not be jacked up any longer, the jack would just go right through the pinch weld area for it.Ôªø

author: hamzah keramat hussain

text:
You all act like the consumer market available to US manufacturers hasn't been shrinking for the last half century. If they make good products that last and satisfy the customer, the company would just go out of business. The market is already saturated and people aren't making new consumers like they used to. Even if they were, jobs are being replaced by tech and moved to lower paying regions.

The only way for our society to mass produce high quality products again is to either have a massive and unsustainable spike in the birth rate or make the majority of the country so devastatingly poor that the entire consumer market can be rebuilt from scratch.

Profitability since the 1970s is just too low to justify making products that won't be repurchased as quickly as possible.Ôªø

author: ChickenC0re

text: Not exactly. Modern cars have taken great strides for reliability as apposed to say, 30 years ago. Remember tune-ups? With out the occasional tune up, an old car would break down and leave you stranded. Now, without components that need tuning and better production quality since the switch to automated assembly, a modern car can go 10k miles between oil changes (with synthetic oil). And because of all the electronics, cars can compensate for wear as the vehicle ages. Not even mentioning the car's ability so self-diagnose, cars today are much more reliable than they were in the past. I get the logic of simple means reliable, but car's are not simple. Not now, not in the past. I presume most people who hate modern cars are frustrated because they dont understand how they work. Hell, I was like that for a long time too.Ôªø

text:
I got locked in my 2005 Volvo V50.
Was waiting for a family member, turned car off took key fob out of ignition laid it on dash. Few minutes later car locked itself? Thought the family member had accidentally hit their key fob? Pulled on door handle got a click in door lock but didn‚Äôt release lock, pout key fob in ignition and turned, nothing! Key not found appeared on instrument panel. Removed key, tried again repeatedly same result. Tried door handle again and again just the click but no unlock.

Family member came out and at first their led didn‚Äôt work either, had to use the real key from outside to override the lock. 2nd key did not work in ignition either, key not found?

After a tow to our repair shop it was found to be the ignition module to the tune of $600, everything else workedÔªø

text:
When my Battery went out.. and my alternator went...
I could still open my doors.
I physically didn't even have the ability to have flashers.. cause the battery and alternator were dead.
I could still open my doors, hatch and get stuff out.

When I had to go out and get a new window regulator for my pass side...
I took the old one out, put the new one in (after the old one spent 2 weeks, being duct taped to the paint and forced to stay up until i could find the time and get the new one put in). When I put it in... I put every damn thing back together. (The power connector for the door and windows, reconnected the locking metal for the interior and exterior. All of the little damn pieces.)

05 Honda ELEMENT. 
I taught my 1yr old boy.. what my car is.
SQUARE.
BLUE
HONDA.

Be surprised how ya cant miss that car in a parking lot.

P.S
There's nothing complicated... anywhere on that car. No computers. No screens. Nothing. While the idiot sales guy was yammering on about some bullshit. He didn't even have the sense to tell me it had hydraulic steering (as I backed it into a spot). Idiot didn't even know what it was. Lousy blockhead.Ôªø

author: Jose M. Molina Ocampo

text:
@-T-X-M-
About the Wagon R, it has a boxy shape and therfore  plenty of head room, leg room and interior space, both in the front and the back. Boot space is pretty low though.

As for driving in the city, it's a great little car cz it can fit into little gaps in traffic and can easily find parking spots. Plenty of road feel though the steering too.

But on the highway, at very high speeds (around 80km/h and above, it can  feel a bit unstable (floaty feeling). There's noticeable body roll when making turns.

When attempting to overtake or merging to  a highway however , you'll have to plan well in advance cz with  the 660cc engine and the CVT combo, it takes a while to get upto speed.

Fuel economy is good if you keep the engine rpms below 2000 ( which is near impossible most of the time), if not the economy is just average unfortunately :(

I find it really difficult to reach advertised fuel figures and I drive only in the city.

As for the tech, the auto emergency breaking is just plain bad. Gets activated when you make crucial turns at junctions but never when needed, so it's better to turn it off  or not purchase that option at all.

Visibility all around the vehicle is good, there's a backup cam as well.
Reliability so far has been really good, 12,000km over 2 years with city driving only, no issues so far.

Service recommended at every 5000km though.
The mild hybrid system is disappointing and the stop / start feature can be a pain sometimes.

Hope this is useful ‚úåüèª

I'm not very familiar with that Mercedes, will check it out üëçüèªÔªø

text:
The high beltline is because designers think it looks better. That's really it. The majority of side impact protection is door overlap with any pillars, and the impact beams in the doors. 

If you look at pictures of side impact protection, it's really just high strength steel pillars and door sills, a metal or plastic impact bar running diagonally through the door. I mean, yes, more metal will absorb more impact, but it really doesn't add that much

Another theory  is to reduce the  greenhouse and load on the ac system. But it's stupid because they make cars with tiny windows than put panoramic sunroofs, which puts glass at the worse part of the car.Ôªø

author: Jellyfrosh

text: @Jellyfrosh No I am saying that just because a car is electric, doesn't  mean it cant have a transmission. It's just that the typical cars people think of when talking electric (Tesla, Renault, BMW, etc) don't use multi-speed transmissions in their current models. However, it is still possible to buy electric cars that do have multi speed transmissions, and the bigger companies are developing transmissions for their future ev cars too. The statement "electrics don't have a transmission at all" is false, as it categorizes all electric vehicles as one, which is wrong. It also leads people to believe that electric cars can't have multi-speed transmissions, which is also wrong.Ôªø

author: herrdoktorprofessor

text:
NatoriousGamePlay 
You mustn‚Äôt have watched the video (different channel) about why we have plastic headlights now.

From Wikipedia:

‚ÄúIn 1968 when Federal auto equipment and safety regulations were initiated, the requirement for two large or four small round sealed beams was codified, freezing headlamp design for many years. At the same time, the new regulations prohibited any decorative or protective element in front of the headlamps whenever the headlamps are switched on. Glass-covered headlamps, used on e.g. the Jaguar E-Type, pre-1968 VW Beetle, 1965 Chrysler and Imperial models, Porsche 356, Citro√´n DS and Ferrari Daytona were no longer permitted and vehicles had to be imported with uncovered headlamps for the US market. This change meant that vehicles with headlamp configurations designed for good aerodynamic performance could not achieve it for the US market.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn 1983, granting a 1981 petition from Ford Motor Company, the US headlamp regulations were amended to allow replaceable-bulb, nonstandard-shape, architectural headlamps with aerodynamic lenses that could for the first time be plastic. This allowed the first US-market car since 1939 with replaceable bulb headlamps: the 1984 Lincoln Mark VII. These composite headlamps were sometimes referred to as "Euro" headlamps, since aerodynamic headlamps were common in Europe. Though conceptually similar to European headlamps with non-standardized shape and replaceable-bulb construction, these headlamps conform to the SAE headlamp standards of US Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 108, and not the internationalized European safety standards used outside North America. Nevertheless, this change to US regulations largely united headlamp styling within and outside the North American market.‚Äù

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/HeadlampÔªø

harry:
one aspect of the point i was making is that there is nothing in modern cars control wise that is truly intuitive. hell...just look at the shifters. there aren't even any cables attached to an automatic tranny anymore. your input is merely a suggestion for the government under the hood. same goes for the throttle(dbw) and now,even the brakes. all computer controlled. when these cpu's take a shit the car will be bricked in 5 to 10 years because of three little letters: NLA(no longer available) and DMCA bullshit.
with each model year the level of cars becoming appliances(much like a freezer or fridge)increases exponentially. if a driver is looking for a true driving experience then the quest will be long,hard and most of all...expensive. all the tech is accomplishing these days are allowing people who,because of their lack of attention span,to get behind the wheel and wreak havoc on the road and others on it. tech in cars is more than a distraction because it requires your attention(eyes off the road)instead of muscle memory and the brain's memory centres.
   i could write a dissertation on this but this isn't the place.  my opinion on this though is that if one cannot drive a car proper then public transportation or a cab is the answer...not that bloody tech and all the excessive garbage that goes with it. as for me...i will stick to my '94 v12 jag.Ôªø

author: polaris911

text:
That is not correct. 
You can thank the EPA for stop/start and other bs features (eco button anyone?). Consumers done want that crap. Every new model IQS survey I read has people bitching about idle stop. The powertrain engineers certainly don't want that crap. Do you think the calibration and controls guys like working on something which the majority of people, including themselves, hate? 
It's just a method of ticking a box for a fuel economy label credit - applying idle stop is basically +1mpg in the US FE city mode (enough that you can round up to the next integer).

And it's the same with cylinder deactivation, eleventeen speed transmissions, turbocharging, eco mode, etc. The real world impact is fuck all (or worse, negative real world impact), but it makes the number bigger in this one standard test mode so we have to apply it, because every other manufacturer is applying it to make their number bigger. And consumers like bigger numbers, so we must apply it too.Ôªø

author: Bradford Ramm

text:
A lot of features are packaged together, want alloy rims or slightly larger wheels? 
Well I hope you want Sunroof/LDWS/ACC/Lane watch assist/FCWS/Autonomous braking system/key less entry system/key less start/Infotainment system. 
I opposed Key less entry (but it grew on me), Infotainment system needs more real buttons in case the LCD breaks. It had more real buttons than the Subaru, but I still want less LCD requirement buttons. LDWS/ACC/Lane watch assist is cool, but autonomous braking system activates with curves in the road with vehicles in opposing direction. 

Like the back up camera though, but worry about longevity of all these bells and whistles, along with the extra hole in the car for sunroof.Ôªø

If someone made a brand new 2004 Toyota Corolla would you pay full price new for it? Most would say they wanted better gas mileage, but then would complain about the CVT. Or want the rear back up camera, but don't want the LCD infotainment screen. They would want GPS options as well. 
It is hard to find that happy medium, especially when the dealers are going to get stuck with a car they can't sell. More options are more problems for the dealers. 
Each of these are double edged blades for people.Ôªø

I ain't buying them. Speak for yourself, I never had nor do I want to buy a newer vehicle then approx. 2001 model year. Cars 15-20 years ago had a lot of electronic garbage but never to the point that you felt that you're sitting in a jetplane. What we need today in newer vehicles is less electronics and more mechanical parts as old-modern cars had 15-25 years ago.Ôªø

Add in the interest paid on that marginal cost (and since it's a marginal cost, it doesn't fall under the interest-free down payment-- it's ALL financed), and then add up the cost of that bad habit over a lifetime of car-buying, and you're into an added cost that could pay for some major medical bills or a year of college tuition.Ôªø

text: I have a 2018 Corolla 6mt with 30,000 km in it since April. While it‚Äôs a lovely car and has everything I need as a daily commuter, and it‚Äôs also beating its fuel rating , it‚Äôs very under powered in manual configuration. Be prepared to be downshifting for every hill on the highway and in headwinds and for any sort of acceleration. Sometimes 6th down to 4th. Everything else is spot on. Backseats in the se upgrade trim, are probably the most comfortable back seats of any vehicle I have sat in and I‚Äôm 5‚Äô11‚Äù with 33‚Äù inseam. Very pleased with the car overall but you must note acceleration is lacking. I commute 200 km per day in it on the highway.Ôªø
